name: Tylenol
dosage: 500-1000 mg orally every 4-6 hours as needed (max ~3000 mg per day for adults)
indications: Mild to moderate pain, fever reduction
contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment or active liver disease; hypersensitivity to acetaminophen
side_effects: Generally well tolerated; possible nausea, rash; hepatotoxicity in overdose
mechanism_of_action: Inhibits prostaglandin synthesis in the central nervous system, leading to analgesic and antipyretic effects (with minimal anti-inflammatory action)
drug_interactions: Excessive alcohol use increases risk of liver damage; concurrent use with other acetaminophen-containing products can lead to overdose

name: Advil
dosage: 400-800 mg orally every 6-8 hours as needed (for pain/fever); max 3200 mg/day
indications: Mild to moderate pain, fever, and inflammatory conditions (such as arthritis, muscle aches)
contraindications: Active gastrointestinal bleeding or ulcer, severe renal impairment; history of NSAID-induced asthma or urticaria
side_effects: Upset stomach, nausea, heartburn; risk of GI ulceration or bleeding, elevated blood pressure, kidney dysfunction
mechanism_of_action: Reversibly inhibits COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes, reducing prostaglandin synthesis which results in analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and antipyretic effects
drug_interactions: Concurrent use with warfarin or other blood thinners increases bleeding risk; may reduce antihypertensive efficacy; concomitant use with other NSAIDs or corticosteroids heightens GI injury risk

name: Aspirin
dosage: 325-650 mg orally every 4-6 hours as needed (for pain/fever); low dose 81 mg daily for antiplatelet effect
indications: Pain, fever, inflammation (high dose); prevention of cardiovascular events (low dose antiplatelet)
contraindications: Active peptic ulcer disease, bleeding disorders; children or teenagers with viral infections (risk of Reye's syndrome)
side_effects: Gastric irritation or ulceration, bleeding, tinnitus (at high doses)
mechanism_of_action: Irreversibly inhibits COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes, reducing prostaglandin and thromboxane A2 production, leading to analgesic, anti-inflammatory, antipyretic, and antiplatelet effects
drug_interactions: Concurrent use with anticoagulants or other NSAIDs increases bleeding risk; may reduce efficacy of antihypertensives; use with methotrexate can raise methotrexate levels

name: Aleve
dosage: 250-500 mg orally twice daily (every 12 hours) as needed, with food; max 1000-1500 mg/day
indications: Pain and inflammation in conditions like osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, gout, menstrual cramps
contraindications: Active gastric ulcer or GI bleeding; NSAID-induced asthma or allergic reaction history; advanced renal failure
side_effects: Stomach pain, heartburn, nausea; GI ulcer or bleeding (with long-term use), kidney function impairment
mechanism_of_action: Reversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1 and -2, leading to decreased prostaglandin synthesis which reduces inflammation, pain, and fever
drug_interactions: Increased bleeding risk if combined with anticoagulants or other NSAIDs; may reduce effect of ACE inhibitors or diuretics; concurrent lithium use can raise lithium levels (NSAIDs reduce lithium excretion)

name: Celebrex
dosage: 200 mg orally once daily or 100 mg twice daily
indications: Osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis pain and inflammation; acute pain; dysmenorrhea (menstrual cramps)
contraindications: Sulfonamide allergy; history of asthma or allergic reaction to NSAIDs; perioperative pain in CABG surgery
side_effects: Dyspepsia, hypertension, increased risk of thrombotic events; lower risk of GI ulcer than non-selective NSAIDs
mechanism_of_action: Selectively inhibits cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2), decreasing prostaglandin synthesis involved in inflammation (with less inhibition of COX-1 in gut and platelets)
drug_interactions: May increase risk of bleeding with anticoagulants; co-administration with ACE inhibitors or diuretics may reduce their effectiveness; levels can be increased by CYP2C9 inhibitors (like fluconazole)

name: Voltaren
dosage: 50 mg orally three times daily (enteric coated) or 75 mg twice daily (extended release); use lowest effective dose
indications: Moderate pain and inflammation from osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, acute musculoskeletal injuries
contraindications: Active peptic ulcer or GI bleeding; history of asthma or urticaria with NSAIDs; advanced renal or hepatic failure
side_effects: Abdominal pain, nausea, elevated liver enzymes; risk of GI ulceration or bleeding, edema, and increased blood pressure
mechanism_of_action: Reversibly inhibits COX-1 and COX-2, reducing the formation of prostaglandins involved in pain, fever, and inflammation
drug_interactions: Use with other NSAIDs or corticosteroids elevates GI risk; may increase lithium and digoxin levels (by reducing their renal clearance); concurrent warfarin heightens bleeding risk

name: Mobic
dosage: 7.5 mg orally once daily (may increase to 15 mg once daily if needed)
indications: Osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis (relief of signs and symptoms such as joint pain and inflammation)
contraindications: Active GI ulcer or bleeding; NSAID allergy or asthma sensitivity; severe renal insufficiency without dialysis
side_effects: Dyspepsia, nausea, diarrhea; risk of GI bleeding or ulcer (especially at higher doses), edema, headache
mechanism_of_action: Preferentially (but not exclusively) inhibits COX-2 over COX-1, decreasing prostaglandin synthesis and thereby reducing inflammation and pain
drug_interactions: Combined use with anticoagulants or antiplatelets increases bleeding risk; cholestyramine can increase meloxicam clearance; concomitant ACE inhibitors may have reduced efficacy and increased renal risk

name: Indocin
dosage: 25-50 mg orally two to three times daily (max 200 mg/day) with food; 50 mg rectal suppository twice daily for acute pain
indications: Moderate to severe inflammatory conditions: rheumatoid arthritis, gouty arthritis (acute gout flares), ankylosing spondylitis
contraindications: History of proctitis or rectal bleeding (for suppository); active peptic ulcer; severe renal impairment; NSAID-exacerbated asthma
side_effects: Nausea, gastrointestinaI pain, headache, dizziness; GI ulceration or bleeding, elevated blood pressure, fluid retention
mechanism_of_action: Non-selective inhibitor of COX-1 and COX-2, which reduces prostaglandin synthesis to alleviate inflammation and pain
drug_interactions: Probenecid can increase indomethacin levels (reduces excretion); co-administration with antihypertensives (ACEi, ARB) may reduce their effect; concurrent use with other NSAIDs or corticosteroids heightens GI risk

name: Toradol
dosage: 30 mg IV/IM every 6 hours (maximum 120 mg/day) for up to 5 days, or 10 mg orally every 4-6 hours (max 40 mg/day, oral used only as continuation of IV/IM)
indications: Short-term management of moderate to severe acute pain (often post-surgical) — typically not to exceed 5 days of use
contraindications: Active peptic ulcer or recent GI bleed; advanced renal impairment; risk of bleeding (e.g., cerebrovascular bleeding); use before major surgery or during labor/delivery; hypersensitivity to NSAIDs
side_effects: GI pain, nausea, dyspepsia; risk of serious GI bleeding or ulceration (especially with longer use), renal impairment, and increased bleeding tendency
mechanism_of_action: Potent non-selective COX-1/2 inhibitor, leading to significant prostaglandin reduction; provides analgesic efficacy comparable to opioids in some cases, as well as anti-inflammatory effects
drug_interactions: Concurrent use with other NSAIDs or aspirin increases risk of GI bleeding; enhances bleeding risk with anticoagulants; concomitant probenecid significantly increases ketorolac levels (contraindicated)

name: OxyContin
dosage: 10-30 mg orally every 4-6 hours as needed for pain (immediate-release); extended-release tablets dosed 10-80 mg every 12 hours (opioid-tolerant patients for higher doses)
indications: Moderate to severe pain requiring an opioid analgesic (acute or chronic pain management)
contraindications: Severe respiratory depression, acute or severe asthma, paralytic ileus; hypersensitivity
side_effects: Constipation, drowsiness, nausea, respiratory depression; pruritus (itching)
mechanism_of_action: Mu-opioid receptor agonist in the central nervous system, altering pain perception and response
drug_interactions: Use with CNS depressants (e.g., sedatives, alcohol) increases risk of profound sedation and respiratory depression; some CYP3A4 inhibitors (like clarithromycin) can increase oxycodone levels leading to toxicity

name: Duragesic
dosage: 25 µg/hour transdermal patch applied every 72 hours (titrate by 25 µg/hr increments for pain control in opioid-tolerant patients); for acute pain (IV): 25-50 µg IV bolus titrated for effect
indications: Severe chronic pain (e.g., cancer pain) in opioid-tolerant patients (transdermal patch); acute pain management and anesthesia adjunct (IV form)
contraindications: Opioid-naïve patients (transdermal form); significant respiratory depression; acute or postoperative pain (patch form); known hypersensitivity
side_effects: Respiratory depression, severe sedation, constipation; nausea; patch: application site reactions
mechanism_of_action: Potent mu-opioid receptor agonist with rapid onset and short duration (IV) or extended release (transdermal), providing analgesia
drug_interactions: Dangerous sedation or respiratory depression with other CNS depressants; CYP3A4 inhibitors (e.g., azole antifungals) can increase fentanyl levels; MAOIs may cause serotoninergic effect with fentanyl (rare)

name: MS Contin
dosage: Morphine sulfate extended-release: 15-30 mg orally every 8-12 hours (titrated for chronic pain). Immediate release: 10-30 mg orally every 4 hours as needed
indications: Moderate to severe acute or chronic pain (such as post-surgical pain, cancer pain) where use of an opioid is appropriate
contraindications: Significant respiratory depression, acute or severe asthma in unmonitored settings; paralytic ileus; hypersensitivity
side_effects: Sedation, respiratory depression, constipation, nausea, urinary retention
mechanism_of_action: Mu-opioid receptor agonist that alters perception and response to pain and produces CNS depression (analgesia and sedation)
drug_interactions: Additive CNS depression with benzodiazepines, alcohol, or other sedatives can be dangerous; concomitant MAOIs may cause unpredictable severe reactions; other opioids or agonist-antagonists (like buprenorphine) can precipitate withdrawal or reduce effect

name: Ultram
dosage: 50-100 mg orally every 4-6 hours as needed (max 400 mg/day for immediate release)
indications: Moderate pain, chronic pain where a weaker opioid analgesic is appropriate
contraindications: Acute intoxication with alcohol, hypnotics, or other opioids; uncontrolled epilepsy; use of MAOIs within 14 days
side_effects: Dizziness, nausea, constipation, drowsiness; at high doses, risk of seizures or serotonin syndrome
mechanism_of_action: Weak mu-opioid receptor agonist and inhibits reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, altering pain signaling
drug_interactions: Risk of serotonin syndrome when combined with SSRIs, SNRIs, or MAOIs; carbamazepine can reduce tramadol levels; other CNS depressants have additive sedation

name: Vicodin
dosage: 5 to 10 mg hydrocodone with 300-325 mg acetaminophen orally every 4-6 hours as needed for pain
indications: Moderate to moderately severe pain
contraindications: Significant respiratory depression, acute bronchial asthma (unmonitored setting); severe hepatic impairment (due to acetaminophen content)
side_effects: Drowsiness, constipation, nausea; hepatotoxicity in overdose (from acetaminophen)
mechanism_of_action: Hydrocodone is a mu-opioid receptor agonist providing analgesia; acetaminophen inhibits prostaglandin synthesis in the CNS to reduce pain and fever
drug_interactions: Concurrent use with benzodiazepines or alcohol can increase sedation and respiratory depression; combining with other acetaminophen-containing products can lead to liver damage

name: Suboxone
dosage: Sublingual film: 4 mg buprenorphine/1 mg naloxone (one film) to start, titrated for maintenance (usual maintenance 12-16 mg/3-4 mg buprenorphine/naloxone daily)
indications: Opioid dependence maintenance therapy (to prevent withdrawal and reduce cravings)
contraindications: Opioid hypersensitivity; severe respiratory insufficiency
side_effects: Constipation, headache, withdrawal syndrome (if other opioids are present), oral mucosal irritation (from film/tablet)
mechanism_of_action: Buprenorphine is a partial mu-opioid agonist that alleviates withdrawal and cravings; naloxone is an opioid antagonist included to deter intravenous abuse (it precipitates withdrawal if injected)
drug_interactions: Use with benzodiazepines or other CNS depressants can increase sedation and respiratory depression; precipitated withdrawal may occur if taken with full opioid agonists (buprenorphine can displace other opioids)

name: Narcan
dosage: 0.4-2 mg IV/IM/subQ repeated every 2-3 minutes as needed for opioid overdose (intranasal formulation: 4 mg spray in one nostril, may repeat)
indications: Opioid overdose reversal; reversal of opioid-induced respiratory depression in emergency situations
contraindications: None in acute opioid overdose (opioid dependence is a caution due to precipitating withdrawal, but not a contraindication in emergency)
side_effects: Acute opioid withdrawal symptoms (agitation, nausea/vomiting, rapid heart rate, sweating) in opioid-dependent individuals; pain return (reversal of analgesia)
mechanism_of_action: Opioid receptor antagonist that competitively binds mu (and kappa) receptors, displacing opioid agonists and reversing their effects on CNS and respiratory depression
drug_interactions: Can precipitate withdrawal in patients on opioid agonists or agonist-antagonists; no significant pharmacokinetic drug interactions as it is used acutely and has short duration

name: Methadose
dosage: 5-10 mg orally every 8-12 hours for pain (dosing is highly individualized); for opioid dependence, typical dosing 80-120 mg orally once daily (titrated to prevent withdrawal)
indications: Severe chronic pain; opioid dependence detoxification or maintenance therapy (in a federally regulated program)
contraindications: Respiratory depression, acute bronchial asthma without resuscitative equipment; concurrent MAOI use; known or suspected paralytic ileus
side_effects: Sedation, constipation, respiratory depression, QT interval prolongation (risk of serious arrhythmia), sweating
mechanism_of_action: Long-acting mu-opioid receptor agonist; also an NMDA receptor antagonist. Suppresses withdrawal symptoms and cravings in opioid dependence and provides long-lasting analgesia in chronic pain
drug_interactions: CYP3A4 inhibitors (e.g., azoles, some SSRIs) or CYP2D6 inhibitors can increase methadone levels (risk of toxicity); inducers (rifampin, phenytoin) lower levels (risk of withdrawal); additive sedation with other CNS depressants; risk of torsades de pointes if combined with other QT-prolonging agents

name: Xylocaine
dosage: Apply 5% topical patch to affected area once daily for up to 12 hours (for post-herpetic neuralgia); or 50-100 mg by infiltration for local anesthesia (dosage varies by procedure)
indications: Local anesthesia for minor surgical or dental procedures; topical pain relief (e.g., post-herpetic neuralgia via patch); treatment of ventricular arrhythmias (IV lidocaine)
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to amide local anesthetics; Adam-Stokes syndrome, Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (for IV use in arrhythmia); severe heart block without pacemaker (IV use)
side_effects: Local numbness, irritation at site of application; if absorbed systemically: drowsiness, dizziness, tinnitus, or cardiac arrhythmias in overdose
mechanism_of_action: Blocks voltage-gated sodium channels in neurons, preventing initiation and conduction of nerve impulses (stabilizes neuronal membranes), which produces localized anesthesia
drug_interactions: Use with other antiarrhythmics can increase cardiac depression; beta-blockers or cimetidine can decrease lidocaine clearance leading to higher blood levels; adding epinephrine locally prolongs lidocaine's anesthetic effect (via vasoconstriction)

name: Marcaine
dosage: 0.25% to 0.5% solution infiltrated locally or used in nerve block; dose depends on procedure (e.g., 5-20 mL for major nerve blocks; epidural 10-20 mL of 0.25-0.5%)
indications: Local or regional anesthesia for surgical, obstetric (epidural for labor), or dental procedures (nerve block, spinal anesthesia)
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to amide anesthetics; obstetrical paracervical block (associated with fetal bradycardia); severe shock or heart block (for epidural)
side_effects: Hypotension, bradycardia (especially with epidural or spinal use); CNS toxicity (tinnitus, seizures) or cardiac arrhythmias if injected intravascularly or if excessive blood levels occur
mechanism_of_action: Amide local anesthetic that blocks sodium ion channels in nerve fibers, preventing the propagation of action potentials and resulting in loss of sensation in the area supplied by those nerves
drug_interactions: Use with other local anesthetics or class I antiarrhythmics can potentiate systemic toxic effects; drugs that reduce hepatic blood flow (e.g., beta-blockers) may reduce bupivacaine metabolism, increasing toxicity risk

name: Amoxil
dosage: 500 mg orally every 8 hours (or 875 mg every 12 hours) for most infections; pediatric dosing varies by weight
indications: Infections caused by susceptible bacteria: otitis media, sinusitis, streptococcal pharyngitis, bronchitis, pneumonia, urinary tract infections, etc.
contraindications: Allergy to penicillins (beta-lactams); caution if history of cephalosporin allergy (possible cross-reactivity)
side_effects: Nausea, diarrhea, rash; potential antibiotic-associated colitis (Clostridioides difficile infection) with broad use
mechanism_of_action: Beta-lactam antibiotic (penicillin family) that inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins, leading to cell lysis (bactericidal)
drug_interactions: Probenecid decreases renal excretion, increasing amoxicillin levels; may reduce efficacy of oral contraceptives (alteration of gut flora); allopurinol can increase incidence of amoxicillin rash

name: Augmentin
dosage: 500 mg amoxicillin/125 mg clavulanate orally every 8-12 hours, or 875/125 mg every 12 hours (dose depends on infection severity)
indications: Bacterial infections including sinusitis, otitis media, respiratory tract infections, skin infections, and UTIs caused by beta-lactamase producing organisms
contraindications: History of amoxicillin-clavulanate–associated cholestatic jaundice or hepatic dysfunction; penicillin allergy
side_effects: Diarrhea (common due to clavulanate), nausea, skin rash; rarely, liver enzyme elevations or hepatitis
mechanism_of_action: Amoxicillin inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis (penicillin action); clavulanate inhibits beta-lactamase enzymes produced by resistant bacteria, thus protecting amoxicillin from degradation
drug_interactions: Probenecid prolongs amoxicillin levels by reducing renal excretion; may reduce efficacy of oral contraceptives; allopurinol with amoxicillin can increase rash incidence

name: Keflex
dosage: 500 mg orally every 6 hours (or 250 mg every 6 hours for mild infections)
indications: Skin and soft tissue infections, streptococcal pharyngitis, uncomplicated urinary tract infections caused by susceptible bacteria
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to cephalosporins; use with caution in patients with severe penicillin allergy
side_effects: Diarrhea, nausea, rash; possible allergic reactions (cross-reactivity in penicillin-allergic patients ~5-10%)
mechanism_of_action: First-generation cephalosporin (beta-lactam); inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins, causing cell lysis (bactericidal)
drug_interactions: Probenecid can increase cephalexin levels by reducing renal excretion; may enhance warfarin effect by reducing vitamin K–producing gut flora (monitor INR if on warfarin)

name: Rocephin
dosage: 1-2 g IV/IM once daily (or divided twice daily) for most infections; 250 mg IM once for uncomplicated gonorrhea
indications: Broad range of infections: community-acquired pneumonia, meningitis, gonorrhea, pyelonephritis, intra-abdominal infections (with metronidazole), Lyme disease (neurologic), etc.
contraindications: Serious cephalosporin allergy; neonates (<28 days) with hyperbilirubinemia (risk of kernicterus) or receiving IV calcium solutions (risk of precipitate formation)
side_effects: Injection site pain (IM), diarrhea, biliary sludging (causing pseudocholelithiasis); allergic reactions; yeast superinfection
mechanism_of_action: Third-generation cephalosporin; inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins. Broad spectrum bactericidal activity including many gram-negatives and streptococci (penetrates blood-brain barrier)
drug_interactions: Forms precipitate with IV calcium solutions in neonates (avoid concurrent use in neonates); may potentiate warfarin's effect by altering gut flora (monitor coagulation); aminoglycosides combined with ceftriaxone can have additive antibacterial effect against some organisms

name: Zithromax
dosage: 500 mg on day 1, then 250 mg once daily on days 2-5 ("Z-Pak" for many infections); alternative: 500 mg daily ×3 days
indications: Community-acquired pneumonia, bronchitis, sinusitis, pharyngitis (as penicillin alternative), skin infections, chlamydial infections (single-dose 1 g), traveler's diarrhea (certain cases)
contraindications: History of cholestatic jaundice/hepatic dysfunction with prior azithromycin use; hypersensitivity to macrolides
side_effects: Diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea; QT interval prolongation (rare risk of arrhythmia); transient elevated liver enzymes
mechanism_of_action: Macrolide antibiotic; binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit of bacteria, inhibiting protein synthesis (bacteriostatic, but can be bactericidal at high concentrations or against certain organisms)
drug_interactions: Antacids (aluminum/magnesium) can reduce azithromycin absorption (separate dosing); although azithromycin has fewer CYP interactions than erythromycin, it can still enhance warfarin effect (monitor INR); avoid other QT-prolonging drugs if possible due to additive risk

name: Cipro
dosage: 500 mg orally every 12 hours (or 400 mg IV every 12 hours) for most infections; duration depends on infection type (e.g., 7-14 days for complicated UTI)
indications: Urinary tract infections, bacterial diarrhea (traveler's diarrhea), intra-abdominal infections (with metronidazole), bone/joint infections, Pseudomonas infections, anthrax (post-exposure)
contraindications: Concurrent tizanidine use; hypersensitivity to fluoroquinolones; children or adolescents (caution, due to cartilage toxicity, except in specific serious infections)
side_effects: Nausea, diarrhea, dizziness; tendonitis or tendon rupture (rare, higher risk in older patients)​:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}; QT prolongation; photosensitivity
mechanism_of_action: Fluoroquinolone antibiotic; inhibits bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, preventing DNA replication and transcription (bactericidal)
drug_interactions: Antacids or supplements containing calcium, magnesium, or iron significantly reduce absorption (take 2 hours apart); can increase plasma levels of theophylline and warfarin (monitor therapy); concurrent corticosteroids may heighten tendon rupture risk

name: Levaquin
dosage: 500-750 mg orally or IV once daily (depending on infection type) for 5-10 days (acute infections) or longer for complicated infections
indications: Community-acquired pneumonia, sinusitis, pyelonephritis, chronic prostatitis, skin infections, and inhalational anthrax post-exposure; broad coverage including respiratory pathogens and some Pseudomonas activity
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to fluoroquinolones; epilepsy or history of tendon disorders related to quinolone use (relative contraindications); in children/pregnancy (unless no alternative)
side_effects: Nausea, headache, insomnia; tendonitis/tendon rupture (rare) especially in older adults; potential QT prolongation; peripheral neuropathy (rare)
mechanism_of_action: Fluoroquinolone antibiotic; inhibits bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, interfering with DNA replication and repair, leading to bacterial cell death
drug_interactions: Absorption reduced by antacids or iron/zinc supplements (separate dosing by a few hours); concurrent use with antiarrhythmics or other QT-prolonging drugs may increase arrhythmia risk; can potentiate effect of warfarin (monitor INR)

name: Bactrim
dosage: 800 mg SMX / 160 mg TMP (one double-strength tablet) orally every 12 hours
indications: Urinary tract infections, acute bronchitis exacerbations, Pneumocystis pneumonia (treatment and prophylaxis), Traveler’s diarrhea, MRSA skin infections (off-label)
contraindications: Sulfonamide allergy; marked hepatic or renal impairment; infants <2 months (risk of kernicterus)
side_effects: Nausea, vomiting, rash (mild to severe like Stevens-Johnson syndrome), hyperkalemia (especially in high dose or renal impairment), photosensitivity, bone marrow suppression (rare)
mechanism_of_action: Combination blocks two sequential steps in folate synthesis: sulfamethoxazole (SMX) inhibits dihydropteroate synthase and trimethoprim (TMP) inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, resulting in bactericidal activity when combined
drug_interactions: Enhances warfarin's effect (can raise INR and bleeding risk)​:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}; concurrent use with ACE inhibitors or spironolactone can increase risk of hyperkalemia; may increase levels/toxicity of phenytoin and methotrexate by inhibiting their metabolism/clearance

name: Vancocin
dosage: 15-20 mg/kg IV every 8-12 hours for systemic infections (dose and interval adjusted by levels and renal function); 125 mg orally 4 times daily for C. difficile colitis
indications: Serious gram-positive infections, including MRSA infections (bacteremia, endocarditis, pneumonia, skin) and enterococcal infections; **Oral form**: Clostridioides difficile colitis
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to vancomycin; (no absolute contraindications in severe infections aside from allergy)
side_effects: Red Man syndrome (flushing, hypotension if infused too fast), nephrotoxicity at high doses or with other nephrotoxic drugs, ototoxicity (rare), neutropenia (long-term)
mechanism_of_action: Glycopeptide antibiotic; inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala termini of peptidoglycan precursors, preventing cross-linking (bactericidal against most gram-positive organisms)
drug_interactions: Other nephrotoxic agents (e.g., aminoglycosides, amphotericin B) increase risk of kidney damage; when given with general anesthetics, rapid infusion can enhance histamine release (causing Red Man syndrome); no significant CYP-mediated interactions

name: Flagyl
dosage: 500 mg orally or IV every 8 hours for most anaerobic infections (7-14 days); 2 g orally once for trichomoniasis; 500 mg orally 3 times daily for 10-14 days for C. difficile
indications: Anaerobic bacterial infections (intra-abdominal, pelvic, dental infections), protozoal infections (Trichomoniasis, Giardiasis, amoebiasis), Clostridioides difficile colitis, bacterial vaginosis
contraindications: First trimester of pregnancy for trichomoniasis; use of alcohol during therapy or within 3 days of discontinuation (disulfiram-like reaction); hypersensitivity to metronidazole or nitroimidazoles
side_effects: Nausea, metallic taste, headache, abdominal cramps; disulfiram-like reaction with alcohol (flushing, vomiting); peripheral neuropathy or CNS effects (with prolonged use)
mechanism_of_action: After entering anaerobic organisms, it is reduced to reactive metabolites that damage DNA and other macromolecules, leading to cell death (effective against anaerobic bacteria and certain protozoa)
drug_interactions: Ethanol ingestion causes severe nausea/vomiting and flushing (disulfiram-like reaction); increases warfarin effect by inhibiting metabolism (monitor INR); co-administration with lithium can raise lithium levels/toxicity

name: Cleocin
dosage: 300 mg orally every 6 hours (typical); 600-900 mg IV every 8 hours for severe infections
indications: Skin and soft tissue infections (especially due to Streptococci or Staphylococci, including some MRSA), anaerobic infections, aspiration pneumonia, dental infections, acne (topical form)
contraindications: Previous Clostridioides difficile colitis from clindamycin; hypersensitivity to clindamycin or lincomycin
side_effects: Diarrhea (common), which can be severe and lead to C. difficile colitis; nausea, abdominal pain; rash
mechanism_of_action: Lincosamide antibiotic; binds to the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes, suppressing protein synthesis (generally bacteriostatic, bactericidal at high concentrations or against some organisms)
drug_interactions: May potentiate neuromuscular blocking agents (additive muscle relaxation); antagonistic if used with erythromycin (overlapping binding site); not a major CYP inhibitor/inducer, so few drug metabolism interactions

name: Zyvox
dosage: 600 mg orally or IV every 12 hours for 10-14 days (depending on infection; up to 28 days for chronic infections)
indications: Infections caused by resistant gram-positive bacteria: MRSA pneumonia or skin infections, vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE) infections (e.g., enterococcal bacteremia or UTIs)
contraindications: Concurrent or recent (within 2 weeks) use of MAO inhibitors (linezolid has MAOI activity); uncontrolled hypertension or pheochromocytoma (caution, due to potential serotonin syndrome or hypertensive reactions with tyramine foods)
side_effects: Headache, diarrhea, thrombocytopenia or anemia (especially with >2 weeks use), peripheral neuropathy and optic neuropathy (with prolonged use), serotonin syndrome (when combined with SSRIs)
mechanism_of_action: Oxazolidinone antibiotic; binds to 23S rRNA of the 50S ribosomal subunit, preventing formation of the initiation complex in bacterial protein synthesis (bacteriostatic against staphylococci and enterococci, bactericidal against most streptococci)
drug_interactions: As a weak MAOI, it can precipitate serotonin syndrome when combined with SSRIs, SNRIs, or other serotonergic drugs​:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}; avoid large amounts of tyramine-rich foods (risk of hypertension); concomitant adrenergic agents can cause blood pressure elevation

name: Vibramycin
dosage: 100 mg orally or IV twice daily
indications: Broad spectrum: acne vulgaris, Lyme disease, Rocky Mountain spotted fever (rickettsial diseases), chlamydial infections, community-acquired pneumonia (atypical coverage), sinusitis, malaria prophylaxis, etc.
contraindications: Pregnancy (second/third trimester) and children <8 years old (due to tooth discoloration and bone growth effects); hypersensitivity to tetracyclines
side_effects: Photosensitivity (sunburn risk), esophagitis (if taken without water), GI upset; tooth discoloration in developing teeth (in children), disturbance of bone growth (with chronic use in young children)
mechanism_of_action: Tetracycline antibiotic; binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit, preventing attachment of tRNA to the ribosome acceptor site, thereby inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis (bacteriostatic)
drug_interactions: Absorption is decreased by calcium, iron, magnesium, and aluminum (avoid dairy or antacids within 2 hours); may enhance effect of warfarin by reducing vitamin K–producing gut flora; can reduce efficacy of oral contraceptives (debated, but often counseled)

name: Nizoral
dosage: 200-400 mg orally once daily (for systemic infection) – *oral use is limited due to side effects; topical forms applied once or twice daily for skin infections*
indications: Topical fungal infections (cream or shampoo for seborrheic dermatitis, tinea); historically used orally for systemic fungal infections (candidiasis, coccidioidomycosis, etc.), but largely replaced by safer azoles
contraindications: Co-administration with certain CYP3A4 metabolized drugs (e.g., cisapride, certain statins) due to serious arrhythmias; acute or chronic liver disease (for systemic use)
side_effects: Nausea, vomiting, hepatotoxicity (including rare liver failure), adrenal insufficiency (inhibits steroid synthesis), gynecomastia in males (with long-term use due to inhibition of androgen synthesis)
mechanism_of_action: Imidazole antifungal; inhibits fungal 14-alpha demethylase (a CYP450 enzyme), blocking ergosterol synthesis in fungal cell membranes, leading to increased membrane permeability and growth arrest
drug_interactions: Strong inhibitor of CYP3A4: can markedly increase levels of many drugs (like terfenadine, leading to arrhythmia)​:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}; antacids and PPIs decrease ketoconazole absorption (needs acidic pH); coadministration with hepatotoxic drugs raises risk of liver injury

name: Diflucan
dosage: 150 mg orally as a single dose for vaginal candidiasis; 200 mg on day 1, then 100-200 mg daily for invasive or mucosal infections (duration varies by infection)
indications: Candida infections (vaginal yeast infection, oropharyngeal thrush, invasive candidiasis), cryptococcal meningitis, coccidioidomycosis (valley fever)
contraindications: Concurrent use of CYP3A4 substrates that can prolong QT (e.g., cisapride, terfenadine) due to risk of arrhythmia; hypersensitivity to fluconazole or other azoles
side_effects: Headache, nausea, abdominal pain; reversible elevation of liver enzymes; QT prolongation (rare); alopecia (with long-term use)
mechanism_of_action: Triazole antifungal; inhibits fungal cytochrome P450 14-alpha demethylase, preventing conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol in fungal cell membranes, thus exerting fungistatic or fungicidal effects depending on concentration and organism
drug_interactions: Moderate inhibitor of CYP3A4 and strong inhibitor of CYP2C9: can increase levels of warfarin (bleeding risk), phenytoin, sulfonylureas, and certain benzodiazepines; rifampin can enhance fluconazole clearance (reducing effectiveness)

name: Zovirax
dosage: 400 mg orally three times daily (for 7-10 days in initial genital herpes); IV dosing ~5-10 mg/kg every 8 hours for severe infections (e.g., encephalitis)
indications: Herpes simplex virus infections (genital herpes, cold sores), herpes zoster (shingles), varicella (chickenpox). IV form for herpes encephalitis or severe HSV/VZV infections
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to acyclovir or valacyclovir; caution in dehydration or renal impairment (dose adjustment needed)
side_effects: Nausea, diarrhea, headache; IV form: nephrotoxicity (crystal nephropathy) if inadequate hydration; rare neurotoxicity (agitation, confusion) in high doses or renal failure
mechanism_of_action: Guanosine analog antiviral; converted to acyclovir triphosphate inside infected cells, where it competitively inhibits viral DNA polymerase and causes premature DNA chain termination in herpes viruses
drug_interactions: Probenecid can decrease acyclovir renal clearance (increasing levels); other nephrotoxic drugs (e.g., IV contrast, cyclosporine) can increase risk of kidney injury; zidovudine coadministration may enhance CNS side effects (somnolence)

name: Tamiflu
dosage: 75 mg orally twice daily for 5 days (treatment of influenza in adults); 75 mg once daily for 10 days (post-exposure prophylaxis)
indications: Treatment of acute influenza A and B infection (within 48 hours of symptom onset to be effective); prophylaxis of influenza in high-risk individuals after exposure
contraindications: Known serious hypersensitivity to oseltamivir; caution in patients with fructose intolerance (suspension contains sorbitol)
side_effects: Nausea, vomiting (typically mild and often improving if taken with food); headache; rare neuropsychiatric events (confusion, hallucinations) mainly reported in pediatric patients
mechanism_of_action: Neuraminidase inhibitor; inhibits the influenza virus neuraminidase enzyme, preventing release of new viral particles from infected host cells, thus limiting infection spread in respiratory tract
drug_interactions: Live attenuated influenza vaccine (intranasal) efficacy may be reduced if oseltamivir is given around the time of vaccination (avoid use 48h before to 2 weeks after vaccine); otherwise minimal significant drug interactions

name: Retrovir
dosage: 300 mg orally twice daily (in combination with other antiretrovirals); IV dosing 1-2 mg/kg hourly for perinatal HIV prophylaxis during labor
indications: HIV-1 infection (as part of combination antiretroviral therapy); prevention of maternal-fetal HIV transmission during childbirth (IV zidovudine)
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to zidovudine; markedly low neutrophil count (<1000) or anemia (Hgb <7.5 g/dL) can preclude use until corrected due to bone marrow suppression
side_effects: Bone marrow suppression (anemia, neutropenia), headache, nausea, myopathy (with long-term use), nail discoloration (bluish pigment)
mechanism_of_action: Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI); thymidine analog that, once phosphorylated inside cells, is incorporated by viral reverse transcriptase into proviral DNA, causing chain termination and inhibiting HIV replication
drug_interactions: Other bone marrow suppressants (like ganciclovir or interferon) increase hematologic toxicity; co-administration with ribavirin or stavudine is antagonistic (avoid stavudine with zidovudine); fluconazole and other drugs can increase zidovudine levels by inhibiting glucuronidation

name: Kaletra
dosage: 400 mg lopinavir/100 mg ritonavir (two tablets) orally twice daily with food; or 800/200 mg once daily (if no prior resistance)
indications: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV-1) infection, in combination with other antiretroviral agents (as a component of HAART therapy)
contraindications: Coadministration with drugs highly dependent on CYP3A for clearance (due to ritonavir’s potent inhibition) such as certain antiarrhythmics, sedatives, or ergot derivatives; known hypersensitivity
side_effects: Diarrhea, nausea, elevated cholesterol and triglycerides; hepatotoxicity (rarely severe); lipodystrophy with long-term use; hyperglycemia
mechanism_of_action: Lopinavir is an HIV protease inhibitor that prevents cleavage of viral polyproteins, resulting in noninfectious virus. Ritonavir is a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor included at a low dose to increase lopinavir levels (boosting its efficacy)
drug_interactions: Numerous interactions via CYP3A4​:contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}: contraindicated with rifampin (induces metabolism, lowering levels) and drugs like amiodarone or midazolam (due to ritonavir inhibiting their metabolism); St. John's Wort reduces lopinavir levels; requires careful review of concomitant medications

name: Sovaldi
dosage: 400 mg orally once daily (in combination with other antiviral agents) for 12 weeks (typical for many HCV genotypes, longer with cirrhosis or certain genotypes)
indications: Chronic Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection (genotypes 1-4 in combination with other antivirals such as ribavirin, peginterferon, or other direct-acting antivirals depending on genotype)
contraindications: Co-administration with potent P-gp inducers (e.g., rifampin, St. John's Wort) which can significantly reduce sofosbuvir levels; hypersensitivity
side_effects: Fatigue, headache, nausea; in combination therapy, side effects may include those of other agents (e.g., anemia with ribavirin)
mechanism_of_action: Nucleotide analog prodrug that, once activated to GS-461203 (sofosbuvir triphosphate), inhibits the HCV NS5B RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, causing chain termination in viral RNA replication
drug_interactions: Potent P-glycoprotein inducers (rifampin, carbamazepine) can significantly decrease sofosbuvir plasma concentration and reduce its therapeutic effect (contraindicated); co-administration with amiodarone is not recommended due to cases of serious bradycardia when used with another DAAs

name: Harvoni
dosage: One tablet (90 mg ledipasvir/400 mg sofosbuvir) orally once daily for 12 weeks (typical for genotype 1 HCV without cirrhosis; duration may vary with cirrhosis or other genotypes)
indications: Chronic Hepatitis C virus infection, genotypes 1, 4, 5, or 6 (achieves sustained virologic response in a high percentage of patients)
contraindications: Concurrent use of potent P-gp inducers (e.g., rifampin, St. John's Wort) that can reduce drug levels; severe bradycardia risk with amiodarone co-use; hypersensitivity
side_effects: Fatigue, headache, nausea; bradycardia (rare, when taken with amiodarone); generally well tolerated
mechanism_of_action: Ledipasvir inhibits the HCV NS5A protein, which is essential for viral RNA replication and assembly; sofosbuvir (a nucleotide analog) inhibits the HCV NS5B RNA polymerase. The combination halts viral replication at two different targets
drug_interactions: Concurrent use with amiodarone can cause serious symptomatic bradycardia (avoid combination)​:contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}; antacids, H2 blockers, and proton pump inhibitors can reduce ledipasvir absorption (separate dosing or avoid high doses of PPIs); potent inducers (rifampin, carbamazepine) may decrease Harvoni efficacy

name: Nydrazid
dosage: 300 mg orally once daily (for active TB, given with other drugs) or 900 mg twice weekly (directly observed therapy); 300 mg daily for 6-9 months for latent TB infection
indications: Treatment of active tuberculosis (in combination with other antitubercular agents); latent tuberculosis infection as monotherapy to prevent progression to active disease
contraindications: Acute liver disease; previous severe isoniazid-induced hepatic injury; hypersensitivity to isoniazid
side_effects: Peripheral neuropathy (due to pyridoxine [vitamin B6] depletion, preventable with B6 supplementation), elevated liver enzymes or hepatitis, rash, fatigue
mechanism_of_action: Prodrug activated by mycobacterial catalase-peroxidase (KatG); once active, it inhibits synthesis of mycolic acids (essential components of the mycobacterial cell wall), leading to bacterial cell death (bactericidal for actively dividing TB)
drug_interactions: Inhibits CYP enzymes: can increase levels of phenytoin, carbamazepine (dose adjustments needed); alcohol and rifampin co-use greatly increase risk of liver toxicity; tyramine-rich foods or histamine (e.g., fish) can cause flushing or blood pressure changes due to monoamine oxidase inhibition effect

name: Rifadin
dosage: 600 mg orally once daily (for tuberculosis, in combination therapy); or 600 mg 2-3 times weekly in DOT therapy; prophylaxis for meningococcal exposure: 600 mg twice daily for 2 days
indications: Active tuberculosis (with other agents); latent TB (alternative to isoniazid); eradication of Neisseria meningitidis carriage; certain staphylococcal infections (adjunct, like MRSA with prosthetic devices); atypical mycobacteria
contraindications: Concomitant use with certain antivirals (some protease inhibitors) or antifungals (e.g., voriconazole) that are contraindicated due to rifampin’s enzyme induction (use rifabutin instead in HIV patients); hypersensitivity
side_effects: Orange-red discoloration of urine, sweat, tears (harmless but can stain); hepatotoxicity; flu-like syndrome with intermittent dosing; thrombocytopenia (rare immune-mediated)
mechanism_of_action: Ansamycin antibiotic; inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase in bacteria (especially mycobacteria), thereby preventing RNA synthesis. Bactericidal against Mycobacterium tuberculosis and many other bacteria
drug_interactions: Powerful inducer of CYP3A4 and other enzymes​:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}, leading to reduced effectiveness of many drugs (e.g., oral contraceptives, warfarin, protease inhibitors, azole antifungals); concurrent use with those often requires substitution or dosage adjustments; avoid with combination of certain antivirals (unless adjusted) as it can cause treatment failure

name: Myambutol
dosage: 15-25 mg/kg orally once daily (typical dose 1200-1600 mg in adults) for active TB in combination therapy; or 50 mg/kg twice weekly (DOT therapy)
indications: Active tuberculosis (in combination with isoniazid, rifampin, and pyrazinamide); Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infections as part of multi-drug regimen
contraindications: Optic neuritis (pre-existing, since drug can exacerbate); inability to report visual changes (young children or uncooperative patients, use with caution)
side_effects: Optic neuritis (dose-related; blurred vision, red-green color discrimination loss), which is usually reversible if caught early; peripheral neuropathy (rare); rash
mechanism_of_action: Inhibits arabinosyl transferase, an enzyme involved in mycobacterial cell wall carbohydrate (arabinogalactan) synthesis, thus impairing cell wall formation (bacteriostatic against Mycobacterium tuberculosis)
drug_interactions: Aluminum-containing antacids can decrease ethambutol absorption (separate dosing by a few hours); no significant CYP interactions; coadministration with other TB drugs (isoniazid, rifampin) has no contraindication (they are complementary)

name: Plaquenil
dosage: 200-400 mg orally once daily (for rheumatoid arthritis or lupus maintenance); for acute malaria, 800 mg base dose, then 400 mg at 6, 24, 48 hours
indications: Rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus (disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drug); prophylaxis and treatment of malaria (for susceptible strains); certain autoimmune dermatologic conditions
contraindications: Retinal or visual field changes attributable to hydroxychloroquine; hypersensitivity to 4-aminoquinoline compounds
side_effects: Retinal toxicity (vision changes) with long-term use, corneal deposits, nausea, skin hyperpigmentation, headache; safe in pregnancy for lupus (low risk but still monitored)
mechanism_of_action: Immune modulator: accumulates in lysosomes and likely interferes with antigen processing and presentation, and synthesis of inflammatory mediators (in lupus/RA); as an antimalarial, it raises intravacuolar pH and interferes with parasite's ability to digest hemoglobin
drug_interactions: Additive risk of QT prolongation if combined with other QT-prolonging agents (use caution); may increase levels of digoxin (monitor levels); co-administration with mefloquine can increase risk of seizures; avoid use with other drugs that cause retinal toxicity

name: Aralen
dosage: 500 mg (300 mg base) orally once weekly for malaria prophylaxis; for treatment of malaria, 1 g (600 mg base) oral loading, then 500 mg (300 mg base) at 6, 24, 48 hours
indications: Malaria prophylaxis and treatment (for susceptible Plasmodium species in areas without resistance); extraintestinal amebiasis; off-label in rheumatic diseases (limited by side effect profile)
contraindications: Retinal or visual field changes from prior 4-aminoquinoline use; psoriasis or porphyria (can exacerbate these conditions); hypersensitivity
side_effects: GI upset, pruritus (especially in dark-skinned patients), headache, blurred vision; high doses: retinal damage (with long-term use), cardiomyopathy or QT prolongation, neuropsychiatric effects
mechanism_of_action: Antimalarial 4-aminoquinoline: concentrates in parasitized erythrocytes and interferes with heme detoxification by parasites, causing buildup of toxic heme. In autoimmune diseases, mechanism may involve modulation of immune pathways and inhibition of certain enzymes
drug_interactions: Avoid combining with mefloquine (both can lower seizure threshold); cimetidine may increase chloroquine levels; additive QT prolongation with other QT-prolonging drugs (antiarrhythmics, some antibiotics); may raise levels of cyclosporine if used together

name: Lipitor
dosage: 10-80 mg orally once daily (usually in the evening for initial statin, but atorvastatin can be taken any time of day due to long half-life)
indications: Hypercholesterolemia (elevated LDL), mixed dyslipidemia; primary and secondary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (to reduce risk of MI, stroke)
contraindications: Active liver disease or unexplained persistent liver enzyme elevation; pregnancy and breastfeeding (contraindicated due to potential teratogenicity)
side_effects: Headache, myalgia (muscle aches); elevations in liver enzymes; rare but serious: rhabdomyolysis (muscle breakdown) leading to acute renal failure
mechanism_of_action: HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor; blocks the rate-limiting step of cholesterol synthesis in the liver, upregulating LDL receptors and increasing clearance of LDL from the bloodstream​:contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}
drug_interactions: Metabolized by CYP3A4: strong inhibitors (clarithromycin, itraconazole, grapefruit juice in large amounts) can raise atorvastatin levels increasing myopathy risk; use with fibrates or niacin raises risk of rhabdomyolysis; may increase effect of warfarin (monitor INR)

name: Zocor
dosage: 10-40 mg orally once daily in the evening (max 40 mg/day in most patients; 80 mg only if already long-term tolerant due to risk of myopathy)
indications: Hypercholesterolemia (high LDL), mixed dyslipidemia; prevention of cardiovascular events (reduces risk of heart attack, stroke in at-risk patients)
contraindications: Active liver disease; unexplained persistent elevations of serum transaminases; pregnancy and nursing mothers; concomitant use of strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (like itraconazole, protease inhibitors, etc.)
side_effects: Elevated liver enzymes, muscle aches or weakness; in rare cases, rhabdomyolysis with acute renal failure; mild GI disturbances
mechanism_of_action: Inhibits HMG-CoA reductase in the liver, reducing mevalonate and cholesterol synthesis. Lower intracellular cholesterol leads to upregulation of LDL receptors, increasing clearance of circulating LDL cholesterol
drug_interactions: Many interactions via CYP3A4: contraindicated with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (e.g., clarithromycin, ketoconazole) due to severe myopathy/rhabdo risk; limit dose if used with amlodipine or amiodarone (due to increased simvastatin levels); combining with niacin or gemfibrozil heightens muscle injury risk

name: Crestor
dosage: 5-40 mg orally once daily (start 10-20 mg for most, can titrate up; 40 mg reserved for those not reaching LDL goal on 20 mg)
indications: Primary hyperlipidemia (high LDL), mixed dyslipidemia; slowing progression of atherosclerosis; primary prevention of cardiovascular disease in high-risk patients
contraindications: Active liver disease; pregnancy and lactation; hypersensitivity to rosuvastatin
side_effects: Myalgia, constipation, AST/ALT elevations; rare: rhabdomyolysis, tendinopathy; rosuvastatin has a slightly higher risk of causing proteinuria (usually benign) at high doses
mechanism_of_action: Competitive inhibition of HMG-CoA reductase in hepatic cells, reducing cholesterol biosynthesis and increasing hepatic uptake of LDL from blood, thus lowering serum LDL and to a lesser extent triglycerides, modestly raising HDL
drug_interactions: Less CYP metabolism (minor via 2C9) so fewer CYP3A4 issues; cyclosporine markedly increases rosuvastatin levels (max 5 mg if on cyclosporine); gemfibrozil can increase risk of myopathy (avoid or limit statin dose); warfarin effect may be slightly increased (monitor INR)

name: Pravachol
dosage: 40 mg orally once daily (range 10-80 mg daily, typically in the evening)
indications: Hypercholesterolemia (elevated LDL), mixed dyslipidemia; prevention of coronary events in patients with coronary heart disease or at high risk
contraindications: Active liver disease; pregnancy and breastfeeding; hypersensitivity to pravastatin
side_effects: Headache, nausea, muscle pain or weakness; elevated liver enzymes (usually asymptomatic); very rare: rhabdomyolysis leading to acute renal failure
mechanism_of_action: HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor; lowers hepatic cholesterol synthesis, upregulates LDL receptors, and increases clearance of LDL cholesterol from plasma. Pravastatin is somewhat less potent but also less muscle-penetrating than some statins
drug_interactions: Not significantly metabolized by CYP3A4 (less drug interactions); bile acid sequestrants (e.g., cholestyramine) can decrease pravastatin absorption (separate dosing); combining with other lipid-lowering therapies like fibrates or niacin heightens myopathy risk

name: Lasix
dosage: 20-80 mg orally once or twice daily (edema dosing; titrate to response); IV: 20-40 mg IV push, titrate for acute pulmonary edema
indications: Edema due to heart failure, liver cirrhosis, or renal disease (including nephrotic syndrome); acute pulmonary edema; hypertension (less common, alternative diuretic option)
contraindications: Anuria (if no urine output, loop diuretics ineffective); hypersensitivity to furosemide or sulfonamide-derived drugs (sulfa allergy caution, though cross-reactivity is low)
side_effects: Electrolyte imbalances (hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia), dehydration, hypotension; ototoxicity (hearing loss) with rapid IV administration or high doses; hyperuricemia (can precipitate gout)
mechanism_of_action: Loop diuretic; inhibits the Na⁺-K⁺-2Cl⁻ co-transporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, leading to profound diuresis with increased excretion of sodium, chloride, potassium, and water
drug_interactions: Concurrent use with aminoglycosides increases ototoxicity risk; NSAIDs can reduce diuretic effectiveness; with digoxin, hypokalemia from furosemide can increase digoxin toxicity risk; combination with other antihypertensives can cause additive hypotension

name: Microzide
dosage: 12.5-25 mg orally once daily (for hypertension; max 50 mg/day, though higher doses often not more effective and more side effects)
indications: Hypertension; edema associated with mild heart failure or nephrotic syndrome; calcium nephrolithiasis prevention (off-label, as it reduces calcium excretion)
contraindications: Anuria; hypersensitivity to sulfonamide-derived drugs (thiazides are sulfonamides, so caution if severe sulfa allergy)
side_effects: Hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hyperuricemia (may precipitate gout), hyperglycemia (in diabetics), hypercalcemia; dizziness, photosensitivity
mechanism_of_action: Thiazide diuretic; inhibits the Na⁺/Cl⁻ cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron, increasing excretion of sodium, chloride, and water (and promoting potassium excretion), thereby reducing blood volume and blood pressure
drug_interactions: NSAIDs may reduce antihypertensive effect; combining with other antihypertensives can cause additional blood pressure reduction; potentiates digoxin toxicity by causing hypokalemia; lithium excretion is reduced by HCTZ, so lithium toxicity risk increases

name: Aldactone
dosage: 25-50 mg orally once daily (for heart failure or hypertension; can be increased to 50 mg twice daily if needed); in edema or ascites, up to 100 mg/day (max 400 mg/day in severe cases)
indications: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (to improve survival), edema from cirrhosis (ascites), hypertension (adjunct), primary hyperaldosteronism, polycystic ovary syndrome (off-label for androgen symptoms)
contraindications: Hyperkalemia; Addison’s disease (adrenal insufficiency); concomitant use with eplerenone or other potassium-sparing diuretics in the setting of high potassium; significant renal impairment
side_effects: Hyperkalemia, especially in patients with renal dysfunction or on ACEi/ARBs; gynecomastia in males, breast tenderness in females (anti-androgen effect); menstrual irregularities; GI upset
mechanism_of_action: Aldosterone receptor antagonist in the distal nephron (collecting tubules); increases excretion of sodium and water while retaining potassium. Also blocks androgen and mineralocorticoid receptors elsewhere, contributing to anti-androgenic effects
drug_interactions: ACE inhibitors, ARBs, or potassium supplements increase risk of hyperkalemia​:contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}; with digoxin, spironolactone can increase digoxin levels (by reducing clearance); NSAIDs may reduce diuretic effect and renal function when combined

name: Dyrenium
dosage: 100 mg orally twice daily (often given in combination with hydrochlorothiazide as 37.5/25 or 75/50 mg); maximum 300 mg/day
indications: Edema or hypertension (usually used with a thiazide diuretic to counteract hypokalemia)
contraindications: Hyperkalemia; severe renal impairment; concomitant use of other potassium-sparing diuretics or potassium supplements (due to hyperkalemia risk)
side_effects: Hyperkalemia (which can cause muscle weakness, arrhythmias); nausea, vomiting; kidney stone formation (triamterene may precipitate in urine)
mechanism_of_action: Potassium-sparing diuretic; blocks epithelial sodium channels in the late distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct, reducing sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion. Causes mild diuresis and potassium retention
drug_interactions: ACE inhibitors or ARBs increase hyperkalemia risk; other potassium-sparing diuretics or potassium supplements can lead to dangerous hyperkalemia; co-administration with indomethacin has been reported to cause reversible renal failure (caution)

name: Lotensin
dosage: 10 mg orally once daily initially, usual maintenance 20-40 mg/day (single or divided doses) for hypertension
indications: Hypertension; off-label for renal protection in diabetic nephropathy or heart failure (though not FDA-approved for these, other ACE inhibitors are preferred for HF)
contraindications: Pregnancy (especially 2nd/3rd trimesters)​:contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}; history of angioedema with ACE inhibitors; bilateral renal artery stenosis; hypersensitivity to benazepril or other ACEi
side_effects: Dry cough, dizziness, hyperkalemia; angioedema (rare but serious swelling of face/lips); increased serum creatinine (especially if renal artery stenosis)
mechanism_of_action: ACE inhibitor: suppresses conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, leading to vasodilation and decreased aldosterone secretion. Result is lower blood pressure and reduced afterload/preload in heart failure, along with renal protective effects in diabetics
drug_interactions: Concurrent potassium-sparing diuretics or potassium supplements can cause hyperkalemia; NSAIDs may reduce antihypertensive effect and increase renal risk; using with aliskiren in diabetic patients is contraindicated (excess renal and hypotension risk)

name: Vasotec
dosage: 5 mg orally once daily initial, titrate to 10-40 mg/day (single or divided) for hypertension; in heart failure, target ~10-20 mg twice daily
indications: Hypertension; symptomatic heart failure (to improve survival); asymptomatic left ventricular dysfunction; diabetic nephropathy (off-label renal protection)
contraindications: Pregnancy (ACE inhibitors can cause fetal toxicity)​:contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}; history of ACE inhibitor–induced angioedema; bilateral renal artery stenosis
side_effects: Cough (persistent, dry), hypotension, dizziness; hyperkalemia; angioedema (rare but can be life-threatening)
mechanism_of_action: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor; reduces production of angiotensin II and aldosterone, leading to vasodilation and reduced blood volume. Lowers blood pressure and decreases heart failure progression by reducing afterload/preload
drug_interactions: Potassium-elevating agents (e.g., spironolactone, potassium supplements) increase hyperkalemia risk; NSAIDs can attenuate antihypertensive effect and worsen renal function; using with lithium may increase lithium levels/toxicity

name: Prinivil
dosage: 10 mg orally once daily initial (for hypertension), titrate to 20-40 mg daily; in heart failure, start 2.5-5 mg daily, titrate to target ~20 mg daily as tolerated
indications: Hypertension; heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (to improve survival); acute myocardial infarction (to improve survival); diabetic nephropathy (renal protection off-label)
contraindications: Pregnancy (teratogenic in 2nd/3rd trimesters)​:contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}; history of angioedema related to previous ACE inhibitor; hereditary angioedema; bilateral renal artery stenosis
side_effects: Persistent dry cough, dizziness, hyperkalemia (especially in renal impairment or with K-sparing meds); angioedema (rare); renal function changes (slight creatinine rise, more if renal artery stenosis)
mechanism_of_action: ACE inhibitor: blocks conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, causing vasodilation and decreased aldosterone release, which lowers blood pressure and reduces workload on the heart. Also mitigates angiotensin II–mediated remodeling in heart failure
drug_interactions: Combining with potassium-sparing diuretics or supplements can lead to hyperkalemia; NSAIDs may reduce antihypertensive effect and increase kidney injury risk; concurrent aliskiren (direct renin inhibitor) in diabetic patients is contraindicated due to renal risks

name: Cozaar
dosage: 50 mg orally once daily (start), range 25-100 mg daily (single or divided) for hypertension; 50-100 mg daily for diabetic nephropathy or stroke risk reduction
indications: Hypertension; diabetic nephropathy in type 2 diabetes (to slow progression); stroke risk reduction in hypertensive patients with left ventricular hypertrophy; heart failure (off-label alternative to ACEi)
contraindications: Pregnancy (ARB can cause fetal harm)​:contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}; bilateral renal artery stenosis (risk of renal failure); hypersensitivity to losartan or other ARBs
side_effects: Dizziness, hypotension, hyperkalemia; much lower incidence of cough or angioedema than ACE inhibitors (though angioedema is still a rare possibility)
mechanism_of_action: Angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB); selectively blocks AT1 receptors, preventing angiotensin II–mediated vasoconstriction and aldosterone release. Results in vasodilation, reduced blood pressure, and decreased sodium retention
drug_interactions: Potassium supplements or potassium-sparing diuretics increase hyperkalemia risk; NSAIDs combined with ARBs can reduce renal function and antihypertensive effect; do not combine with a direct renin inhibitor (aliskiren) in diabetic patients (risk of renal impairment, hyperkalemia)

name: Diovan
dosage: 80-160 mg orally once daily (start for hypertension), titrate up to 320 mg daily if needed; in heart failure, target 160 mg twice daily
indications: Hypertension; heart failure (NYHA class II-IV) to reduce hospitalization (alternative to ACEi); post-MI in patients with left ventricular dysfunction or failure; diabetic nephropathy (off-label renal protection)
contraindications: Pregnancy (teratogenic)​:contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}; concomitant use of aliskiren in diabetic patients; severe hepatic impairment (for valsartan specifically, caution as clearance is hepatic)
side_effects: Dizziness, hypotension, hyperkalemia; rare angioedema; no cough (unlike ACE inhibitors)
mechanism_of_action: Angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB); selectively inhibits binding of angiotensin II to AT1 receptors, blocking vasoconstriction and aldosterone-secreting effects of angiotensin II. Leads to vasodilation, reduced blood pressure, and lowered aldosterone-mediated volume expansion
drug_interactions: Additive risk of hyperkalemia with potassium-sparing diuretics or supplements; NSAIDs may reduce antihypertensive effect and harm kidney function; combining with ACE inhibitors or aliskiren increases risk of hypotension, hyperkalemia, and renal impairment (avoid especially in diabetics)

name: Norvasc
dosage: 5 mg orally once daily (initial for adults), adjust to 5-10 mg once daily as needed for blood pressure or angina control
indications: Hypertension; chronic stable angina; vasospastic (Prinzmetal’s) angina; coronary artery disease with ongoing angina to reduce risk of hospitalization
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to amlodipine; severe hypotension (systolic <90 mmHg) – caution; cardiogenic shock
side_effects: Peripheral edema, headache, flushing, dizziness, fatigue; reflex tachycardia (less common than with shorter-acting dihydropyridines); gingival hyperplasia (rare)
mechanism_of_action: Calcium channel blocker (dihydropyridine class); inhibits calcium influx into vascular smooth muscle and myocardium. Predominantly causes arterial vasodilation (reducing afterload and blood pressure) with minimal direct effect on heart rate
drug_interactions: Additive hypotension when used with other antihypertensives; grapefruit juice can slightly increase amlodipine levels (CYP3A4 substrate); co-administration with simvastatin increases simvastatin levels (limit simvastatin to 20 mg if used together)​:contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}

name: Tenormin
dosage: 50 mg orally once daily (initial for hypertension/angina), titrate to 50-100 mg once daily; for post-MI, 100 mg once daily maintenance
indications: Hypertension; angina pectoris (chronic); secondary prevention post-myocardial infarction to reduce mortality; off-label for certain tachyarrhythmias or anxiety (performance anxiety)
contraindications: Sinus bradycardia, second or third degree AV block (without pacemaker); overt cardiac failure or cardiogenic shock; severe asthma or COPD (relative, since atenolol is beta-1 selective but not entirely sparing at higher doses)
side_effects: Bradycardia, fatigue, hypotension, dizziness; cold extremities; may mask symptoms of hypoglycemia in diabetics (except sweating); less CNS effects since it is less lipophilic (fewer sleep disturbances than some beta-blockers)
mechanism_of_action: Selective beta-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist (cardioselective beta-blocker); reduces heart rate and contractility, thereby lowering myocardial oxygen demand and blood pressure
drug_interactions: Additive bradycardia or hypotension with other AV node blocking or negative chronotropic drugs (digoxin, diltiazem, verapamil); use with clonidine requires careful management to avoid rebound hypertension (if stopping clonidine, beta-blocker should be tapered off first); NSAIDs can slightly reduce atenolol’s antihypertensive effect

name: Lopressor
dosage: 50 mg orally twice daily (immediate release) for hypertension/angina, maintenance 100-200 mg/day; or 100 mg extended-release once daily (range 100-400 mg); for acute MI: 5 mg IV bolus up to 15 mg, then oral dosing
indications: Hypertension; angina pectoris; heart failure (extended-release form succinate to improve survival); myocardial infarction (acute and secondary prevention); rate control in supraventricular tachyarrhythmias (off-label)
contraindications: Severe bradycardia; second or third degree AV block (without pacemaker); overt heart failure or cardiogenic shock; severe peripheral arterial circulatory disorders; hypersensitivity
side_effects: Fatigue, bradycardia, hypotension, dizziness; can worsen asthma at higher doses (less selective at high doses); sexual dysfunction; may mask tachycardia in hypoglycemia
mechanism_of_action: Selective beta-1 adrenergic blocker that reduces heart rate, myocardial contractility, and cardiac output, thereby lowering blood pressure and myocardial oxygen demand
drug_interactions: Additive negative chronotropy with digoxin or other beta-blockers; use with calcium channel blockers like verapamil/diltiazem increases risk of bradycardia or AV block; CYP2D6 inhibitors (e.g., SSRIs like paroxetine) can increase metoprolol levels; abrupt withdrawal can precipitate angina or MI in ischemic heart disease, so taper

name: Coreg
dosage: 6.25 mg orally twice daily, titrated to 25 mg twice daily (for heart failure or hypertension; max 50 mg twice daily in HF for patients >85 kg)
indications: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (to improve survival); hypertension; left ventricular dysfunction post-MI; angina (off-label)
contraindications: Asthma or related bronchospastic condition (non-selective beta-blockade); second/third-degree AV block or sick sinus (without pacemaker); severe bradycardia; decompensated heart failure requiring IV inotropes; severe hepatic impairment
side_effects: Dizziness, fatigue, hypotension (especially orthostatic hypotension), bradycardia; weight gain/fluid retention; can exacerbate asthma or COPD due to beta-2 blockade; may mask hypoglycemia signs
mechanism_of_action: Non-selective beta-adrenergic blocker *and* alpha-1 blocker; reduces heart rate and contractility (beta-1 effect) while causing vasodilation (alpha-1 blockade). Lowers blood pressure, decreases afterload, and improves cardiac output in heart failure by reducing heart workload and remodeling
drug_interactions: Additive bradycardia or hypotension with other beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers; CYP2D6 inhibitors (like quinidine, fluoxetine) can increase carvedilol levels; coadministration with clonidine requires careful management to avoid rebound hypertension if one is stopped abruptly

name: Inderal
dosage: 40 mg orally twice daily (immediate release) for angina or hypertension, maintenance 80-160 mg/day divided; 80 mg once daily (extended release) can be titrated to 160-320 mg daily
indications: Hypertension; angina; arrhythmias (especially tachyarrhythmias, atrial fibrillation rate control); essential tremor; migraine prophylaxis; performance anxiety (situational anxiety); hypertrophic subaortic stenosis; thyrotoxicosis symptoms
contraindications: Bronchial asthma or severe COPD (due to beta-2 blockade); sinus bradycardia, AV block >1st degree (unless paced); cardiogenic shock; hypersensitivity
side_effects: Fatigue, dizziness, bradycardia; bronchospasm (wheezing, especially in asthmatics); sleep disturbances or nightmares (more with propranolol due to CNS penetration); cold extremities; can exacerbate depression
mechanism_of_action: Non-selective beta-adrenergic receptor antagonist (blocks both beta-1 and beta-2 receptors). Slows heart rate and reduces contractility (beta-1) thereby lowering blood pressure and myocardial oxygen demand; also inhibits beta-2–mediated vasodilation and bronchodilation
drug_interactions: Additive AV nodal suppression with calcium channel blockers like verapamil (risk of bradycardia or hypotension); masks hypoglycemia signs, so caution with insulin; metabolized by CYP1A2 and 2D6 – affected by inhibitors/inducers of these pathways (e.g., cimetidine increases levels, smoking induces CYP1A2 lowering levels); co-use with epinephrine (in local anesthetic) can cause unopposed alpha vasoconstriction (hypertension)

name: Cardizem
dosage: 30 mg orally four times daily (immediate release) for angina or arrhythmias, titrate as needed (usual 120-360 mg/day); or 120-240 mg once daily (extended release) for hypertension or chronic angina (max ~480 mg/day)
indications: Angina pectoris (both effort-related and vasospastic); hypertension; atrial fibrillation/flutter (rate control); PSVT prophylaxis; Raynaud’s phenomenon (off-label)
contraindications: Sick sinus syndrome or 2nd/3rd degree AV block (without pacemaker); hypotension (SBP <90); acute pulmonary edema; severe left ventricular dysfunction; concomitant IV beta-blocker administration
side_effects: Bradycardia, hypotension, edema (peripheral); constipation (less than verapamil but can occur); dizziness, headache; with IV use, can cause arrhythmia or heart block if not careful
mechanism_of_action: Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker; inhibits calcium influx in cardiac pacemaker cells and myocardium (slowing AV nodal conduction and reducing heart rate) and in vascular smooth muscle (causing vasodilation). Thus decreases heart rate and contractility while also lowering blood pressure
drug_interactions: Additive bradycardia or hypotension with beta-blockers or digoxin (also increases digoxin levels by P-gp inhibition); CYP3A4 substrate and inhibitor – can raise levels of drugs like carbamazepine or cyclosporine, and levels increased by azoles or macrolides; do not use with IV beta-blockers (risk of severe hypotension/bradycardia)

name: Calan
dosage: 80-120 mg orally three times daily (immediate release) for angina or arrhythmias; 180-240 mg once daily (extended release) for hypertension (range 180-480 mg daily)
indications: Angina pectoris (especially Prinzmetal's angina), supraventricular tachyarrhythmias (like PSVT and rate control in atrial fibrillation/flutter), hypertension (extended-release formulations), hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (symptom relief)
contraindications: Severe left ventricular dysfunction or overt heart failure; 2nd/3rd degree AV block or sick sinus (unless paced); hypotension (SBP <90); Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome with atrial fibrillation (can paradoxically increase ventricular response)
side_effects: Constipation (common, especially in elderly), bradycardia, hypotension, dizziness, flushing; exacerbation of heart failure if significant LV dysfunction; gingival hyperplasia (rare)
mechanism_of_action: Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker; blocks L-type calcium channels in the AV node (slowing conduction and heart rate) and in cardiac muscle (reducing contractility) as well as vascular smooth muscle (causing vasodilation). This leads to decreased myocardial oxygen demand and lower blood pressure
drug_interactions: Beta-blockers or digoxin in combination increase risk of bradycardia or AV block​:contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}; verapamil inhibits CYP3A4 and P-gp, raising levels of drugs like simvastatin, cyclosporine, and digoxin; grapefruit juice can increase verapamil levels; additive hypotensive effect with other antihypertensives

name: Catapres
dosage: 0.1 mg orally twice daily (for hypertension, initial); increase by 0.1 mg increments weekly (usual range 0.2-0.6 mg/day in divided doses). Transdermal patch: 0.1 mg/24 hr patch applied weekly (titrate to 0.2 or 0.3 mg/24 hr if needed)
indications: Hypertension (usually as a second-line agent); attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (extended-release form, as adjunct); pain management (epidural clonidine for cancer pain); opioid withdrawal symptom relief (off-label)
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to clonidine; avoid in patients at risk for noncompliance (sudden cessation can cause rebound hypertension)
side_effects: Drowsiness, dry mouth, bradycardia, dizziness, constipation; withdrawal phenomenon with rebound high blood pressure if stopped abruptly​:contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}; patch may cause local skin irritation
mechanism_of_action: Central alpha-2 adrenergic agonist; stimulates alpha-2 receptors in the brainstem, which reduces sympathetic outflow (decreased norepinephrine release), leading to lowered peripheral vascular resistance, heart rate, and blood pressure
drug_interactions: Additive sedation with CNS depressants like alcohol, opioids; beta-blockers can exacerbate clonidine withdrawal hypertension if clonidine is stopped first (recommend taper beta-blocker off before clonidine); tricyclic antidepressants may reduce clonidine’s antihypertensive effect (by blocking alpha-2 receptors); combining with other hypotensive agents can cause marked blood pressure reduction

name: Apresoline
dosage: 10 mg orally four times daily initially, titrated to 50 mg four times daily (max 300 mg/day) for hypertension; IV: 10-20 mg by slow injection for hypertensive emergency (repeat as needed)
indications: Moderate to severe hypertension (usually in combination with a beta-blocker and diuretic); heart failure (in combination with nitrates in certain patients, e.g., hydralazine/isosorbide dinitrate in Black patients with HFrEF); hypertensive emergency in pregnancy (alternative to labetalol)
contraindications: Mitral valvular rheumatic heart disease (can worsen it); dissecting aortic aneurysm (reflex tachycardia can extend dissection); hypersensitivity
side_effects: Headache, tachycardia, palpitations, flushing; lupus-like syndrome (arthralgia, rash, fever) with chronic use at higher doses; fluid retention (edema)
mechanism_of_action: Direct vasodilator of arterioles (with little effect on veins); mechanism not fully understood but involves reducing intracellular calcium in smooth muscle. Results in decreased systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure, with reflex sympathetic activation (hence often combined with beta-blocker to counter reflex tachycardia)
drug_interactions: Additive hypotension with other antihypertensives; NSAIDs may reduce hydralazine’s antihypertensive effect (by causing fluid retention); co-administration with beta-blockers is common (beneficial to mitigate reflex effects, not a harmful interaction); hydralazine can increase plasma levels of beta-blockers by decreasing hepatic blood flow

name: Imdur
dosage: 30-60 mg orally once daily in the morning (extended-release form; can titrate to 120 mg once daily if needed); immediate-release: 20 mg twice daily (7 hours apart to allow nitrate-free interval)
indications: Prophylaxis of angina pectoris (long-term management of chronic stable angina); not indicated for acute angina attacks due to slow onset
contraindications: Concurrent use of phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil, tadalafil) due to risk of severe hypotension; acute shock or hypotension; hypersensitivity to nitrates
side_effects: Headache (often persistent), dizziness, orthostatic hypotension, flushing; reflex tachycardia; development of tolerance with continuous use (need nitrate-free interval daily)
mechanism_of_action: Organic nitrate that is metabolized to nitric oxide (NO) in vascular smooth muscle. NO activates guanylate cyclase, raising cGMP levels and causing relaxation of vascular smooth muscle – predominantly venodilation (reducing preload) and to a lesser extent arteriolar dilation (reducing afterload), which decreases myocardial oxygen demand
drug_interactions: Absolutely contraindicated with PDE-5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil) as co-use can precipitate life-threatening hypotension​:contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}; alcohol and other vasodilators can enhance hypotensive effects; additive hypotension with blood pressure-lowering medications; ergot alkaloids' effect may be blunted by nitrates

name: Nitrostat
dosage: 0.4 mg sublingual tablet at onset of chest pain, may repeat every 5 minutes up to 3 doses as needed; transdermal patch 0.2-0.4 mg/hr applied daily (on 12-14 hours, off 10-12 hours); IV infusion titrated from 5 mcg/min upward for acute ischemia or heart failure
indications: Acute relief of angina pectoris (sublingual tablets or spray); prophylaxis of angina (transdermal or oral extended forms); acute myocardial infarction or acute heart failure (IV form to reduce preload and chest pain); hypertensive emergency (IV, if ischemia present)
contraindications: Use of sildenafil or other PDE-5 inhibitors within 24-48 hours (depending on agent)​:contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}; significant hypotension or shock; increased intracranial pressure; severe anemia; hypersensitivity to nitrites or nitrates
side_effects: Headache (very common), flushing, lightheadedness, reflex tachycardia; hypotension (especially if volume depleted or upright); with continuous use, tolerance develops rapidly (requires nitrate-free interval each day to maintain efficacy)
