mechanism_of_action: Vasodilator; nitroglycerin is converted to nitric oxide in vascular endothelium. NO increases cGMP in smooth muscle, leading to relaxation. Primarily venous dilation (reduces preload) and at higher doses arterial dilation (reduces afterload), improving myocardial oxygen balance by decreasing cardiac workload and dilating coronary arteries
drug_interactions: Sildenafil or other erectile dysfunction drugs can cause profound hypotension and are contraindicated​:contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}; alcohol and antihypertensives have additive hypotensive effects; ergot derivatives may have reduced effect due to opposing pharmacodynamics

name: Plavix
dosage: 75 mg orally once daily (with or without a 300-600 mg loading dose in acute coronary syndrome or stenting)
indications: Prevention of atherothrombotic events in patients with recent myocardial infarction, recent ischemic stroke, or established peripheral arterial disease; acute coronary syndrome (NSTEMI/STEMI) in combination with aspirin; post coronary stent placement (to prevent stent thrombosis)
contraindications: Active pathological bleeding (e.g., peptic ulcer, intracranial hemorrhage); hypersensitivity to clopidogrel
side_effects: Bleeding (e.g., epistaxis, GI bleeding, bruising); gastrointestinal upset; rare cases of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP); rash
mechanism_of_action: Thienopyridine antiplatelet agent; an irreversible inhibitor of the platelet P2Y₁₂ ADP receptor. By preventing ADP from activating platelets, it inhibits platelet aggregation for the lifespan of the platelet (7-10 days)
drug_interactions: Concurrent use of proton pump inhibitors like omeprazole may reduce conversion of clopidogrel to active metabolite (via CYP2C19 inhibition) and thus decrease effectiveness; other anticoagulants or antiplatelet agents increase bleeding risk; rifampin can enhance clopidogrel activation (by inducing CYP); NSAIDs add GI bleed risk

name: Brilinta
dosage: 180 mg loading dose, then 90 mg orally twice daily (with low-dose aspirin) for 12 months in acute coronary syndrome or after stent; reduce to 60 mg twice daily after 12-18 months if continuing therapy
indications: Acute coronary syndromes (unstable angina/NSTEMI or STEMI) managed with PCI or medically, to reduce the rate of thrombotic cardiovascular events (usually given with aspirin); also used post-stenting to prevent thrombosis
contraindications: Active pathological bleeding; history of intracranial hemorrhage; severe hepatic impairment
side_effects: Dyspnea (shortness of breath), bleeding (e.g., bruising, epistaxis), hypotension; can cause bradyarrhythmias (ventricular pauses) rarely; increased uric acid and creatinine levels in some patients
mechanism_of_action: Reversible antagonist of the platelet ADP P2Y₁₂ receptor (non-thienopyridine); prevents ADP-mediated platelet activation and aggregation. Ticagrelor’s binding is not prodrug-dependent (active as given) and its antiplatelet effect wears off faster after discontinuation compared to clopidogrel
drug_interactions: Strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (ketoconazole, clarithromycin) increase ticagrelor levels (contraindicated); strong inducers (rifampin) decrease levels and effect; aspirin doses above 100 mg daily reduce ticagrelor effectiveness and are not recommended; other anticoagulants/antiplatelets or NSAIDs increase bleeding risk

name: Coumadin
dosage: Dose individualized to target INR (typical maintenance 2-10 mg orally once daily); initial dosing 5 mg daily in many patients, adjust based on INR after ~2-3 days
indications: Prophylaxis and treatment of venous thrombosis (DVT, PE); prevention of thromboembolic complications in atrial fibrillation or prosthetic heart valves; reduction of stroke risk in atrial fibrillation; post-MI to prevent stroke or reinfarction in certain patients
contraindications: Pregnancy (teratogenic and risk of fetal hemorrhage); active significant bleeding; bleeding diathesis or blood dyscrasias; recent major surgery with high bleeding risk; severe uncontrolled hypertension; noncompliance (relative, due to risk of not monitoring INR)
side_effects: Bleeding (from minor bruising to life-threatening hemorrhage)​:contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}; skin necrosis (rare, usually in patients with protein C or S deficiency within first few days); purple toe syndrome (rare cholesterol microembolization); teratogenic effects if given in pregnancy
mechanism_of_action: Vitamin K antagonist; inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase complex 1 (VKORC1), depleting reduced vitamin K. This impairs hepatic synthesis of vitamin K–dependent clotting factors II, VII, IX, X and proteins C and S, leading to reduced coagulation capacity
drug_interactions: Extensive: many drugs potentiate warfarin (e.g., TMP-SMX, metronidazole, amiodarone inhibit metabolism​:contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}) causing elevated INR, while others reduce effect (rifampin, phenytoin induce metabolism, vitamin K intake reduces INR); NSAIDs and antiplatelets increase bleeding risk without changing INR; consistency in dietary vitamin K is important to avoid INR fluctuations

name: Eliquis
dosage: 5 mg orally twice daily for nonvalvular atrial fibrillation (dose reduce to 2.5 mg BID if at least 2 of: age ≥80, weight ≤60 kg, creatinine ≥1.5); 10 mg BID for 7 days then 5 mg BID for DVT/PE treatment; 2.5 mg BID for DVT prophylaxis post-orthopedic surgery
indications: Prevention of stroke and systemic embolism in non-valvular atrial fibrillation; treatment and prevention of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE); post-operative DVT prophylaxis (hip/knee replacement)
contraindications: Active major bleeding; severe hypersensitivity to apixaban
side_effects: Bleeding (e.g., GI bleeding, intracranial hemorrhage – overall risk somewhat lower than warfarin); anemia; bruising. Lower risk of major bleeding in some studies compared to warfarin
mechanism_of_action: Direct factor Xa inhibitor (selectively and reversibly binds to factor Xa), preventing conversion of prothrombin to thrombin and thus hindering both thrombus formation and thrombin-driven coagulation
drug_interactions: Strong dual CYP3A4 and P-gp inhibitors (like ketoconazole, itraconazole, ritonavir) increase apixaban levels and bleeding risk (dose reduction or avoidance recommended)​:contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}; strong inducers (rifampin, St. John's Wort) reduce efficacy; use with other anticoagulants or antiplatelets raises bleeding risk

name: Xarelto
dosage: 20 mg orally once daily with evening meal (for atrial fibrillation stroke prevention); 15 mg twice daily for 21 days then 20 mg once daily (for DVT/PE treatment); 10 mg once daily (for prophylaxis after knee/hip surgery)
indications: Prevention of stroke in non-valvular atrial fibrillation; treatment of DVT and PE, and reduction of recurrence risk; prophylaxis of DVT after hip or knee replacement; prevention of major cardiovascular events in CAD/PAD (with aspirin, specific indication)
contraindications: Active pathological bleeding; hypersensitivity; avoid in severe hepatic impairment (coagulopathy)
side_effects: Bleeding (major bleeding risk comparable to warfarin overall, with lower intracranial bleed but higher GI bleed incidence in some cases); anemia; abdominal pain
mechanism_of_action: Oral direct factor Xa inhibitor; by blocking factor Xa, it prevents the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin and subsequent formation of fibrin clots
drug_interactions: Drugs that are combined P-gp and strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (like itraconazole, ritonavir) can significantly increase rivaroxaban levels (avoid co-use); combined inducers (rifampin, carbamazepine) can decrease efficacy; other anticoagulants or antiplatelet agents enhance bleeding risk

name: Pradaxa
dosage: 150 mg orally twice daily (for atrial fibrillation stroke prevention or DVT/PE treatment in most patients); reduce to 75 mg BID if severe renal impairment (in AFib, if CrCl 15-30 mL/min in US labeling)
indications: Prevention of stroke and systemic embolism in non-valvular atrial fibrillation; treatment and prevention of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism; prophylaxis of DVT/PE after hip replacement surgery
contraindications: Active bleeding; mechanical prosthetic heart valves (dabigatran contraindicated due to thrombosis risk); hypersensitivity
side_effects: Bleeding (including gastrointestinal bleeding; dabigatran has higher GI bleed risk than warfarin but lower intracranial bleed risk); dyspepsia (indigestion) and gastritis-like symptoms are relatively common
mechanism_of_action: Direct thrombin inhibitor (oral prodrug converted to dabigatran); inhibits both free and fibrin-bound thrombin (factor IIa), preventing conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin and activation of factors V, VIII, XI, XIII, thereby impeding clot formation
drug_interactions: P-glycoprotein inhibitors like dronedarone or ketoconazole can increase dabigatran levels (dose adjust or avoid if CrCl <50); P-gp inducers (rifampin) reduce dabigatran levels (avoid concomitant use); co-use with anticoagulants or antiplatelets elevates bleeding risk; antacids may reduce absorption somewhat but not significantly

name: Lovenox
dosage: 1 mg/kg subcutaneously every 12 hours (or 1.5 mg/kg once daily) for DVT/PE treatment; 40 mg subcutaneously once daily for prophylaxis (moderate risk surgery); 30 mg BID for high-risk (e.g., orthopedic surgery)
indications: Prevention of deep vein thrombosis (especially in surgical or immobile patients); treatment of acute DVT and PE (inpatient or outpatient); acute coronary syndromes (unstable angina, NSTEMI, STEMI) as part of anticoagulation strategy
contraindications: Active major bleeding; history of immune-mediated heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) within past 100 days or circulating antibodies; hypersensitivity to enoxaparin, heparin, or pork products
side_effects: Bleeding, injection site hematoma, mild thrombocytopenia; heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (lower risk than UF heparin but can occur); elevated liver enzymes; skin necrosis (rare)
mechanism_of_action: Low molecular weight heparin; binds and potentiates antithrombin III, which inactivates factor Xa (primarily) and to a lesser extent factor IIa (thrombin). Results in anticoagulation by preventing formation of thrombin and fibrin
drug_interactions: Additive bleeding risk with anticoagulants, thrombolytics, or antiplatelet agents; spinal/epidural anesthesia or puncture can risk spinal hematoma (caution and timing considerations); protamine sulfate can partially reverse enoxaparin effect if needed

name: Lanoxin
dosage: 0.125-0.25 mg orally once daily (maintenance dose for atrial fibrillation or heart failure; lower doses like 0.125 mg in elderly or renal impairment); loading (for AF) 0.5 mg, then 0.25 mg at 6-8 hour intervals cautiously
indications: Rate control in atrial fibrillation (especially in sedentary patients or those with heart failure); heart failure (to improve symptoms and exercise tolerance in HFrEF, though not first-line for mortality benefit)
contraindications: Ventricular fibrillation; digoxin hypersensitivity. Caution in AV block, Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome with AF (can paradoxically increase ventricular rate), and renal impairment (reduce dose)
side_effects: Nausea, vomiting, anorexia; dizziness, headache; cardiac arrhythmias (AV block, atrial tachyarrhythmias, ventricular ectopy) especially in toxicity; visual disturbances (blurred or yellow vision) in toxicity
mechanism_of_action: Cardiac glycoside; inhibits the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase pump in cardiac myocytes, leading to increased intracellular calcium (via Na⁺-Ca²⁺ exchange) and enhanced myocardial contractility (positive inotropy). Also increases vagal tone, slowing AV nodal conduction (useful for rate control in AF)
drug_interactions: Levels increased by P-gp inhibitors like verapamil, amiodarone, dronedarone (reduce digoxin dose when starting these)​:contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}; electrolyte disturbances (hypokalemia, hypercalcemia) from diuretics can exacerbate digoxin toxicity; beta-blockers or other AV nodal blockers have additive effect on heart rate (risk of bradycardia/AV block); use with clarithromycin or itraconazole can raise digoxin levels

name: Cordarone
dosage: Loading for arrhythmia suppression: 800-1600 mg orally daily in divided doses for 1-3 weeks, then maintenance 200-400 mg daily. IV: 150 mg bolus over 10 min for VT/VF, then infusion 1 mg/min for 6h, then 0.5 mg/min for 18h
indications: Ventricular arrhythmias (sustained VT or VF) — treatment and prophylaxis; atrial fibrillation (rhythm control in patients with structural heart disease when other agents fail); supraventricular tachycardias (off-label for refractory cases)
contraindications: Severe sinus node dysfunction causing bradycardia; 2nd/3rd degree AV block (without pacemaker); bradycardia causing syncope; hypersensitivity to iodine or amiodarone; hyperthyroidism; pregnancy (especially in 3rd trimester, relative)
side_effects: Hypotension (IV form), bradycardia; long-term: thyroid dysfunction (hypo- or hyperthyroidism), pulmonary fibrosis (potentially life-threatening), liver enzyme elevations or hepatitis, corneal microdeposits (common), skin photosensitivity and bluish discoloration, peripheral neuropathy
mechanism_of_action: Class III antiarrhythmic (Vaughan Williams) with multiple effects: blocks potassium channels (prolongs repolarization and action potential), blocks sodium channels (slows conduction), has beta-blocking and calcium channel blocking properties. Result is lengthened cardiac action potential and refractory period, slowing heart rate and AV conduction
drug_interactions: Potent CYP inhibitor (CYP3A4, 2C9) and P-gp inhibitor: increases levels of drugs like warfarin (requires dose reduction), digoxin (reduce dose by 50%)​:contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}, statins (max simvastatin 20 mg); additive bradycardia with beta-blockers or calcium blockers; prolongs QT so caution with other QT-prolonging drugs (risk of Torsades is surprisingly low for amiodarone given its other effects but still consider)

name: Glucophage
dosage: 500 mg orally twice daily (or 850 mg once daily) initially, then titrate by 500 mg weekly (or 850 mg every 2 weeks) to effective dose; maintenance typically 1500-2000 mg/day divided (max 2550 mg/day in divided doses)
indications: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (first-line oral agent to improve glycemic control); polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) off-label to improve insulin resistance and anovulation
contraindications: Estimated GFR <30 mL/min (severe renal impairment, risk of lactic acidosis); acute or chronic metabolic acidosis (including DKA); caution in advanced heart failure or significant liver disease due to lactic acidosis risk
side_effects: Diarrhea, abdominal cramping, nausea (common especially at start); vitamin B12 deficiency with long-term use; lactic acidosis (rare but serious, risk increases with renal impairment or tissue hypoperfusion states)
mechanism_of_action: Biguanide antidiabetic; reduces hepatic gluconeogenesis, decreases intestinal absorption of glucose, and improves insulin sensitivity (increases peripheral glucose uptake and utilization). Does not directly increase insulin secretion, hence low risk of hypoglycemia
drug_interactions: Iodinated contrast media can acutely reduce renal function and increase lactic acidosis risk (metformin should be held before and after contrast in certain patients)​:contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}; alcohol can potentiate lactic acidosis risk; cimetidine can increase metformin levels by reducing renal clearance (minor effect); other hypoglycemic agents have additive blood sugar lowering but metformin alone does not typically cause hypoglycemia

name: Januvia
dosage: 100 mg orally once daily (normal renal function); if CrCl <50 mL/min, 50 mg once daily; if CrCl <30, 25 mg once daily
indications: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (to improve glycemic control, used as monotherapy or more often as add-on to metformin or other agents when additional HbA1c reduction is needed)
contraindications: History of serious hypersensitivity reaction to sitagliptin (e.g., anaphylaxis, Stevens-Johnson); caution in pancreatitis history
side_effects: Nasopharyngitis, headache, upper respiratory infection; rare but serious: pancreatitis, severe joint pain (reported), hypersensitivity reactions (angioedema, rash)
mechanism_of_action: DPP-4 inhibitor; inhibits dipeptidyl peptidase-4 enzyme, thereby preventing the breakdown of incretin hormones (GLP-1 and GIP). This increases insulin release and decreases glucagon levels in a glucose-dependent manner (i.e., primarily when blood glucose is high)
drug_interactions: Generally low potential for interactions; can slightly increase digoxin levels (monitor if high dose digoxin); hypoglycemia risk increased if combined with sulfonylureas or insulin (consider dose reduction of those); strong P-gp or CYP3A4 interactions not clinically significant for sitagliptin

name: Diabeta
dosage: 2.5-5 mg orally once daily with breakfast (regular glyburide), titrate by 2.5 mg weekly as needed (max ~20 mg/day, divided if >10 mg); micronized glyburide: 1.5-3 mg daily initial, titrate to max ~12 mg/day
indications: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (to improve glycemic control when diet and other agents are inadequate; often used when cost is a concern or in combination therapy)
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to sulfonylureas; Type 1 diabetes or diabetic ketoacidosis; conditions of severe hypoglycemia tendency (e.g., inability to eat); use caution in renal or hepatic impairment (risk of hypoglycemia)
side_effects: Hypoglycemia (can be prolonged), weight gain; nausea; skin reactions (rash, photosensitivity) occasionally; rare hematologic reactions (blood dyscrasias)
mechanism_of_action: Sulfonylurea class antidiabetic; stimulates insulin release from pancreatic beta cells by binding and closing the ATP-dependent K⁺ channels on the cell membrane, which leads to cell depolarization and insulin secretion. Also reduces glucose output from liver and increases insulin sensitivity slightly
drug_interactions: Other antidiabetic drugs have additive hypoglycemic effect (insulin, other sulfonylureas); beta-blockers can mask hypoglycemia symptoms and prolong hypoglycemia; certain azole antifungals, sulfonamides, or chloramphenicol can enhance sulfonylurea effect (inhibit metabolism), increasing hypoglycemia risk; thiazide diuretics or corticosteroids may elevate blood glucose, antagonizing glyburide's effect

name: Glucotrol
dosage: 5 mg orally once daily 30 minutes before breakfast (immediate release), titrate by 2.5-5 mg increments (divide BID if >15 mg/day) – max 40 mg/day (IR). Extended release: 5 mg once daily with breakfast (max 20 mg/day)
indications: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (to improve glycemic control as monotherapy or in combination with other antidiabetic agents)
contraindications: Type 1 diabetes or diabetic ketoacidosis; known hypersensitivity to sulfonylureas; caution in patients with severe hepatic or renal impairment (predisposed to hypoglycemia)
side_effects: Hypoglycemia (especially if meals are skipped or with excessive dose), weight gain; dizziness; rarely, skin rash or photosensitivity; very rare: hemolytic anemia in G6PD deficiency
mechanism_of_action: Sulfonylurea antidiabetic; stimulates insulin secretion from functioning pancreatic beta cells by binding to the sulfonylurea receptor and inhibiting the beta cell K_ATP channel, causing insulin release. Also enhances peripheral insulin sensitivity modestly over time
drug_interactions: Additive hypoglycemic effect with other diabetes medications (insulin, metformin, etc.) or alcohol; beta-blockers may mask adrenergic symptoms of hypoglycemia and prolong recovery; CYP2C9 inhibitors (e.g., fluconazole) can increase glipizide levels; rifampin or phenytoin may reduce efficacy by increasing metabolism

name: Actos
dosage: 15-30 mg orally once daily, can titrate to 45 mg once daily if needed and if tolerated
indications: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (to improve glycemic control, often as an add-on to metformin or sulfonylureas; not first-line due to side effect profile but useful in insulin resistance)
contraindications: Heart failure NYHA Class III or IV (due to risk of fluid retention/exacerbation)​:contentReference[oaicite:26]{index=26}; active bladder cancer (warning/avoid use in patients with history of bladder cancer); hepatic impairment (ALT >2.5x normal)
side_effects: Weight gain, edema (fluid retention); exacerbation of heart failure; risk of hepatic enzyme elevation; increased risk of fractures in distal extremities (especially in women); bladder cancer risk signal (controversial, seen in some data with long-term high-dose use)
mechanism_of_action: Thiazolidinedione (TZD); agonist of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-gamma (PPAR-γ) nuclear receptor, which increases transcription of genes involved in glucose and lipid metabolism. Improves insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues and reduces hepatic gluconeogenesis, thereby lowering blood glucose without directly stimulating insulin release
drug_interactions: May induce CYP3A4 slightly (can reduce efficacy of oral contraceptives - recommend alternative contraception); gemfibrozil can increase pioglitazone levels (inhibits metabolism); rifampin can decrease pioglitazone levels; concurrent insulin or secretagogues increase risk of edema and hypoglycemia (doses may need adjusting)

name: Victoza
dosage: 0.6 mg subcutaneously once daily for 1 week, then increase to 1.2 mg once daily (maintenance dose); may further increase to 1.8 mg once daily if needed for glycemic control
indications: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (to improve glycemic control, often in patients inadequately controlled on oral agents; also associated with weight loss); **Liraglutide (higher dose as Saxenda)** is approved for chronic weight management
contraindications: Personal or family history of medullary thyroid carcinoma or MEN2 (multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome type 2) due to thyroid C-cell tumor risk in rodents; hypersensitivity to liraglutide; pregnancy (for weight management indication)
side_effects: Nausea (very common initially), vomiting, diarrhea; decreased appetite, possible weight loss; risk of pancreatitis (rare); gallbladder disease (from weight loss); injection site reactions
mechanism_of_action: GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1) receptor agonist; mimics the incretin GLP-1. Enhances glucose-dependent insulin secretion, suppresses inappropriate glucagon secretion, slows gastric emptying, and reduces appetite, thus improving blood glucose control and often leading to weight loss
drug_interactions: Delays gastric emptying, which may impact absorption of oral medications (e.g., may slow absorption of analgesics or antibiotics); use with insulin or sulfonylureas increases risk of hypoglycemia (might need dose adjustments of those); no significant CYP-mediated interactions

name: Jardiance
dosage: 10 mg orally once daily in the morning (can increase to 25 mg once daily if needed and if eGFR adequate)
indications: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (to improve glycemic control and reduce risk of cardiovascular death in adults with T2DM and established CVD); also used in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (to reduce hospitalization risk, as per recent approvals)
contraindications: Severe renal impairment (eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73m²) or on dialysis; type 1 diabetes (risk of ketoacidosis); history of serious hypersensitivity to empagliflozin
side_effects: Increased urination, urinary tract infections, genital yeast infections (due to glycosuria); hypotension (especially in volume-depleted patients); ketoacidosis (rare, even with relatively normal blood sugar in some cases); weight loss; increased LDL cholesterol
mechanism_of_action: SGLT2 (sodium-glucose co-transporter 2) inhibitor; works in the proximal renal tubules to block reabsorption of filtered glucose, leading to increased urinary glucose excretion and thereby lowering blood glucose levels. Also causes osmotic diuresis (mild diuretic effect) contributing to blood pressure reduction
drug_interactions: Diuretics: additive effect can increase volume depletion or hypotension; other antihyperglycemics: risk of hypoglycemia if combined with insulin or secretagogues (since empagliflozin itself rarely causes hypoglycemia); may increase digoxin AUC slightly (monitor digoxin levels if used together); rifampin or other inducers can slightly reduce empagliflozin levels (likely not clinically significant)

name: Humulin R
dosage: Dose individualized per blood glucose (commonly start ~0.2-0.4 units/kg/day split among insulins for T1DM). For Regular insulin specifically: given subcutaneously ~30 minutes before meals, typical dose 4-10 units before meals (adjust based on carb intake and glucose). IV infusion for DKA: e.g., 0.1 units/kg bolus then 0.1 units/kg/hr infusion
indications: Diabetes Mellitus (both Type 1 and Type 2) for glycemic control, particularly around meal times; diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperglycemic emergencies (IV regular insulin infusion); gestational diabetes (if needed)
contraindications: Hypoglycemia (if present, postpone dose); hypersensitivity to insulin or excipients
side_effects: Hypoglycemia (sweating, tremor, confusion, can be severe leading to seizures or unconsciousness if untreated); weight gain; injection site reactions (redness, swelling); over long-term, insulin therapy can rarely cause lipoatrophy or lipohypertrophy at injection sites if not rotated
mechanism_of_action: Exogenous insulin (short-acting). Regular insulin is identical to human insulin; it facilitates glucose uptake into insulin-sensitive tissues (muscle, fat) and inhibits hepatic glucose production. Also promotes protein synthesis and lipogenesis and inhibits lipolysis and proteolysis
drug_interactions: Dose requirements can be increased by corticosteroids, thiazide diuretics, sympathomimetics; dose requirements can be decreased by co-administered oral hypoglycemics, some antidepressants, or ACE inhibitors (increase insulin sensitivity); beta-blockers may mask hypoglycemia adrenergic symptoms and prolong hypoglycemia by impairing counter-regulation

name: Lantus
dosage: Dose individualized (commonly start ~0.1-0.2 units/kg at bedtime for type 2 DM if adding to orals; type 1 DM: roughly half of total daily insulin as glargine, adjusted to fasting glucose). Typical starting dose ~10 units subcutaneously once daily in evening, titrate by 2-4 units every few days to reach fasting glucose goal
indications: Diabetes Mellitus Type 1 and Type 2 (as a long-acting basal insulin to control blood glucose throughout the day and night)
contraindications: Hypoglycemia; hypersensitivity to insulin glargine or formulation components
side_effects: Hypoglycemia; weight gain; injection site pain or reactions; potential for slight edema or sodium retention; over long-term, high doses might contribute to insulin resistance; rare allergic reactions (insulin allergy is uncommon but possible)
mechanism_of_action: Long-acting insulin analog (insulin glargine): formulated to precipitate in subcutaneous tissue, releasing insulin slowly. Provides a relatively constant baseline insulin level (no pronounced peak) lasting roughly 24 hours, aiding glucose uptake and suppressing hepatic glucose production
drug_interactions: Similar to other insulins: hypoglycemic effect can be increased by oral antidiabetics, ACE inhibitors, MAOIs, salicylates; effect can be reduced by corticosteroids, thiazide diuretics, thyroid hormones, sympathomimetics; beta-blockers mask hypoglycemia symptoms; alcohol can cause hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia unpredictably

name: Humalog
dosage: Individualized. Often 0.5-1.0 units per 10-15 g carbohydrate for meal coverage, or roughly 0.1 unit/kg per meal as starting estimate. Inject subcutaneously within 15 minutes before a meal or immediately after starting a meal
indications: Diabetes Mellitus Type 1 and Type 2 (for prandial glucose control – rapid-acting insulin analog given around mealtimes); hyperglycemic emergencies (IV off-label usage in hospital if needed, though Regular insulin is more common IV)
contraindications: Hypoglycemia; hypersensitivity to insulin lispro or any excipients
side_effects: Hypoglycemia (particularly if meal is delayed or missed after dose); weight gain; injection site reactions or lipodystrophy with repeated use of same site; very rare systemic allergic reactions
mechanism_of_action: Rapid-acting insulin analog. Insulin lispro has two amino acids reversed compared to human insulin, which prevents hexamer formation, allowing quick absorption. It mimics physiological insulin release after meals, facilitating glucose uptake into muscle/fat and suppressing hepatic glucose output
drug_interactions: Requirements may be increased by drugs like corticosteroids, sympathomimetics, and decreased by drugs like oral antidiabetics, ACE inhibitors. Beta-blockers may mask signs of hypoglycemia; alcohol can unpredictably affect glucose (often causes hypoglycemia by inhibiting gluconeogenesis); additive hypoglycemia with other antidiabetics

name: Synthroid
dosage: 1.6 mcg/kg orally once daily (typical full replacement dose in primary hypothyroidism for otherwise healthy adults). Common starting doses: 50-100 mcg daily, adjust by 12.5-25 mcg increments every 4-6 weeks based on TSH. Take in the morning on empty stomach, 30-60 min before food
indications: Hypothyroidism of any cause (primary, secondary, congenital) as thyroid hormone replacement; TSH suppression in thyroid cancer management or nodules
contraindications: Uncorrected adrenal insufficiency (levothyroxine can precipitate acute adrenal crisis); acute myocardial infarction (caution with initiation due to increased cardiac workload); hypersensitivity to levothyroxine
side_effects: Usually none if dosed correctly. Excess dose leads to signs of hyperthyroidism: palpitations, tachycardia, arrhythmias, anxiety, weight loss, insomnia, osteoporosis long-term. Allergic reactions are rare (inert ingredients possibly)
mechanism_of_action: Synthetic thyroxine (T4) which is converted to active T3 in the body. It binds to thyroid receptor proteins in the cell nucleus and exerts metabolic effects through control of DNA transcription and protein synthesis, thereby increasing metabolic rate of cells and correcting hypothyroid symptoms
drug_interactions: Many interactions affecting absorption: calcium, iron supplements, antacids can chelate levothyroxine and reduce its absorption (separate dosing by 4 hours); estrogen or pregnancy can increase thyroid binding globulin, raising dose requirement; enzyme inducers (rifampin, phenytoin) can increase metabolism of T4; increases effect of warfarin (by catabolism of vitamin K factors) so warfarin dose may need reduction​:contentReference[oaicite:27]{index=27}

name: Tapazole
dosage: Initial: 15-30 mg/day orally (in 3 divided doses or once daily if compliance is good) for mild Graves'; up to 40-60 mg/day for severe hyperthyroidism. Maintenance: 5-15 mg/day once daily. Adjust every 4-6 weeks based on thyroid tests
indications: Hyperthyroidism (Graves' disease) to reduce thyroid hormone production; given prior to radioactive iodine or surgery to achieve euthyroid state; also used in toxic multinodular goiter
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to methimazole; use in first trimester of pregnancy is relatively contraindicated (propylthiouracil preferred in first trimester due to methimazole teratogenic risk like aplasia cutis), though methimazole is preferred in 2nd and 3rd trimesters
side_effects: Rash, pruritus, gastric upset; agranulocytosis (serious, rare idiosyncratic drop in white blood cells – usually within first 3 months; monitor if infection symptoms); hepatotoxicity (less common than with PTU); arthralgias; teratogenic in first trimester (aplasia cutis, embryopathy)
mechanism_of_action: Thionamide antithyroid agent; inhibits thyroid peroxidase enzyme, blocking the oxidation of iodide and the coupling of iodotyrosines (MIT, DIT) to form T3 and T4, thus reducing thyroid hormone synthesis. Does not block release of pre-formed thyroid hormone (so onset of clinical effects is delayed until stored hormone is depleted)
drug_interactions: Can potentiate anticoagulant effect of warfarin by reducing vitamin K activity (if hyperthyroidism state normalized, warfarin metabolism changes) – monitor INR; use with other myelosuppressive agents can increase risk of agranulocytosis; iodine or amiodarone (contains iodine) can antagonize effect by providing iodine substrate

name: Propylthiouracil
dosage: 100 mg orally three times daily (initial for hyperthyroidism); can go up to 300 mg three times daily in thyroid storm (severe cases); maintenance dose may be ~50 mg two or three times daily once euthyroid
indications: Hyperthyroidism (Graves' disease), particularly in the first trimester of pregnancy or thyroid storm; used when methimazole is not tolerated or contraindicated
contraindications: Previous severe adverse reaction to PTU (e.g., agranulocytosis, hepatitis); PTU is generally avoided unless specific indications (like first trimester or intolerance to methimazole) due to higher risk of liver injury
side_effects: Rash, nausea, arthralgias; agranulocytosis (rare but serious); hepatotoxicity including severe liver failure (higher risk than with methimazole)​:contentReference[oaicite:28]{index=28}; ANCA-positive vasculitis (rare, with long-term use); hypothyroidism if dose too high
mechanism_of_action: Thionamide antithyroid: inhibits thyroid peroxidase, blocking iodination of tyrosine residues and coupling reactions in thyroid hormone synthesis. Additionally, PTU (but not methimazole) inhibits peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 (helpful in thyroid storm). Leads to decreased production of T3 and T4
drug_interactions: Additive agranulocytosis risk with other bone marrow suppressants (like some chemotherapy agents); may alter levels of drugs metabolized by changing metabolic rate (e.g., effect on warfarin anticoagulation varies as hyperthyroid state normalizes); iodine-containing medications (like amiodarone) can reduce effectiveness

name: Premarin
dosage: 0.3-0.625 mg orally once daily for menopausal symptoms (individualize lowest effective dose); higher doses (0.625-1.25 mg) for osteoporosis prevention or hypoestrogenism; vaginal cream 0.5 g daily (21 days on, 7 off) for atrophic vaginitis
indications: Moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms of menopause (hot flashes); vulvar and vaginal atrophy due to menopause; hypoestrogenism due to hypogonadism, castration, or ovarian failure; prevention of postmenopausal osteoporosis (when other options unsuitable)
contraindications: Estrogen-dependent neoplasia (e.g., known breast cancer, except in certain metastatic cases); undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding; active or history of thromboembolic disorders (DVT, PE) or stroke/MI; liver dysfunction or disease; known pregnancy
side_effects: Breast tenderness, headache, nausea, bloating; breakthrough bleeding; increased risk of endometrial hyperplasia/cancer if unopposed by progestin in women with uterus; increased risk of thromboembolic events (DVT, PE), stroke​:contentReference[oaicite:29]{index=29}; gallbladder disease; possible slight increase in breast cancer risk with long-term use
mechanism_of_action: Mixture of conjugated equine estrogens (mainly estrone sulfate and equilin). Estrogens bind to estrogen receptors in estrogen-responsive tissues; modulate gene transcription to maintain female secondary sexual characteristics, reduce LH/FSH secretion (alleviating menopausal symptoms), improve vaginal mucosa, and maintain bone density (by reducing bone resorption)
drug_interactions: Inducers of hepatic metabolism (rifampin, some anticonvulsants like phenytoin, carbamazepine) can increase estrogen clearance and reduce efficacy; St. John's Wort can also reduce levels (breakthrough bleeding); estrogens may enhance corticosteroid effects (by increasing binding proteins); thyroid hormone needs may increase (estrogens raise thyroid binding globulin requiring higher levothyroxine dose for same effect); caution with other meds that increase clot risk

name: Estrace
dosage: 0.5-2 mg orally once daily (for menopausal symptoms, adjust to lowest effective); transdermal patch: apply one patch (e.g., delivering 0.05 mg/day) once or twice weekly; estradiol cream: 2-4 g daily (for 1-2 weeks) then taper to maintenance 1-3 times weekly
indications: Moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms of menopause; vulvovaginal atrophy; female hypogonadism or ovarian failure; prevention of postmenopausal osteoporosis (if other options unsuitable); palliative treatment of certain hormone-sensitive cancers (advanced prostate or breast cancer in select cases)
contraindications: Breast cancer (known, suspected, except in appropriately selected patients); estrogen-dependent tumor; undiagnosed abnormal vaginal bleeding; active or history of thromboembolic disorders or stroke; severe liver dysfunction; pregnancy
side_effects: Nausea, breast tenderness, headache, edema; breakthrough uterine bleeding (if uterus intact and no progestin added); increased risk of endometrial cancer if unopposed estrogen in a woman with a uterus; risk of venous thromboembolism, stroke, and gallbladder disease​:contentReference[oaicite:30]{index=30}; possible increased risk of breast cancer with prolonged use; mood changes
mechanism_of_action: Estradiol is the primary human estrogen; it binds to estrogen receptors, regulating gene expression in responsive tissues. Replaces low levels of estrogen in menopause or ovarian failure, alleviating symptoms (hot flashes, vaginal atrophy) and affecting the reproductive system, bone, and cardiovascular system (e.g., lowering LDL, raising HDL, but also prothrombotic effects)
drug_interactions: CYP3A4 inducers (like rifampin, phenobarbital) can increase estradiol metabolism and reduce effectiveness; CYP3A4 inhibitors (itraconazole, erythromycin) might increase estrogen levels; St. John's Wort can reduce estrogen efficacy (and cause breakthrough bleeding); estrogens may alter thyroid hormone requirements as they raise TBG levels (monitor thyroid function in hypothyroid patients); warfarin effect might be slightly reduced by estrogens (monitor INR)

name: Prometrium
dosage: 200 mg orally at bedtime (for 12 days sequentially each 28-day cycle for endometrial protection in postmenopausal HRT); 100 mg at bedtime (daily if used continuously with estrogen); vaginal gel or suppositories for infertility (90 mg gel daily or 100-200 mg suppository 2-3 times daily)
indications: Secondary amenorrhea (to induce withdrawal bleeding); part of hormone replacement therapy (with estrogen) in postmenopausal women with a uterus to prevent endometrial hyperplasia; support of early pregnancy or luteal phase in IVF (via vaginal progesterone formulations); progesterone insufficiency
contraindications: Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding; breast cancer (known or suspected, with some exceptions if being treated in HRT context); active or history of thromboembolic disorders; liver dysfunction or disease; known allergy to peanuts (oral capsules contain peanut oil)
side_effects: Drowsiness (oral micronized progesterone can cause sedation), headache, bloating, mood swings; breast tenderness; irregular bleeding; in some cases, increase in LDL cholesterol; allergic reactions (some formulations)
mechanism_of_action: Progesterone binds to progesterone receptors in the female reproductive tract, breast, and brain. In the uterus, it transforms a proliferative endometrium into a secretory one, and when withdrawn, leads to menses. It also opposes estrogen's proliferative effect on endometrial tissue (preventing hyperplasia). In luteal support, it helps maintain an early pregnancy by improving endometrial receptivity and supporting implantation
drug_interactions: Barbiturates, rifampin, carbamazepine, and other enzyme inducers may increase metabolism of progesterone (reducing levels); ketoconazole and other CYP inhibitors may increase progesterone levels; progesterone may interfere with glucose tolerance (diabetic medications adjustment might be needed); may enhance sedative effect of CNS depressants

name: AndroGel
dosage: 5 g of 1% gel (50 mg testosterone) applied topically once daily (to upper arms/shoulders or abdomen, depending on formulation), adjust dose based on clinical response and serum levels (range 50-100 mg daily); transdermal patch 5 mg/24h at night; IM enanthate 50-100 mg IM weekly or 100-200 mg every 2 weeks
indications: Male hypogonadism (primary or secondary) with associated low testosterone levels and symptoms; delayed puberty in males (to stimulate puberty, short-term use); palliative treatment of metastatic breast cancer in postmenopausal women (rare use)
contraindications: Men with carcinoma of the breast or known or suspected prostate cancer; pregnant women (testosterone is teratogenic); breastfeeding; hypersensitivity to ingredients
side_effects: Skin irritation (with transdermal forms), acne, prostate enlargement (BPH symptoms), increased PSA; erythrocytosis (increased hematocrit); edema; mood swings or aggression; gynecomastia (via aromatization to estrogen); testicular atrophy and infertility (due to HPT axis suppression); high doses or abuse: liver toxicity (especially with oral alkylated forms), dyslipidemia
mechanism_of_action: Exogenous testosterone supplements endogenous levels. Androgen receptor agonist: in target tissues, testosterone or its metabolite dihydrotestosterone binds to intracellular androgen receptors, modulating gene expression to maintain male secondary sexual characteristics, muscle mass, bone density, and sexual function. In hypogonadal men, it restores normal testosterone levels and alleviates symptoms of deficiency
drug_interactions: May enhance effects of oral anticoagulants (monitor INR closely)​:contentReference[oaicite:31]{index=31}; concurrent use with corticosteroids or ACTH may increase edema formation (especially in heart or liver disease); insulin requirements may change (androgens can improve glucose tolerance in some, leading to decreased insulin requirement); hepatic enzyme inducers may reduce testosterone levels from injected forms by increasing metabolism (less an issue with transdermal); testosterone can also alter thyroxine-binding globulin, affecting total T4 (though free T4 remains normal)

name: Ortho Tri-Cyclen
dosage: One oral tablet daily in cyclic regimen: e.g., 0.035 mg ethinyl estradiol + 0.180 mg norgestimate for 7 days, 0.035 mg EE + 0.215 mg norgestimate for 7 days, 0.035 mg EE + 0.250 mg norgestimate for 7 days, then 7 days placebo (repeat cycle). Taken at the same time each day
indications: Contraception (prevention of pregnancy); treatment of moderate acne in females (≥15 years) who desire contraception; regulation of menstrual cycles; reduction of menstrual cramps (dysmenorrhea) and menstrual flow
contraindications: Active or history of thromboembolic disorders or cerebrovascular disease; breast cancer or estrogen-dependent neoplasm; liver tumors or active liver disease; undiagnosed abnormal uterine bleeding; pregnancy; women over 35 who smoke heavily (due to high risk of cardiovascular events)
side_effects: Nausea, breast tenderness, bloating; breakthrough bleeding (especially in first few cycles); headaches; potential elevation in blood pressure; mood changes; increased risk of venous thromboembolism​:contentReference[oaicite:32]{index=32}, myocardial infarction or stroke (especially in smokers >35); slight increase in risk of breast and cervical cancers with long-term use (controversial), but decreased risk of endometrial and ovarian cancer
mechanism_of_action: Combination oral contraceptive: Ethinyl estradiol (an estrogen) and norgestimate (a progestin) work together to suppress gonadotropins. Estrogen suppresses FSH (preventing dominant follicle development) and potentiates progestin action; progestin mainly suppresses LH (preventing ovulation) and thickens cervical mucus (inhibiting sperm passage), as well as alters the endometrium to make it less receptive to implantation
drug_interactions: Enzyme inducers (rifampin, some anticonvulsants like phenobarbital, phenytoin, carbamazepine, St. John's Wort) can increase metabolism of OC hormones and reduce efficacy (risk of breakthrough bleeding/pregnancy)​:contentReference[oaicite:33]{index=33}; some antibiotics (rifampin) clearly reduce levels, others less clear but backup recommended; NNRTIs or protease inhibitors for HIV can alter OC levels (some increase, some decrease); OC may reduce lamotrigine levels (due to induction of lamotrigine glucuronidation), leading to less seizure control; OC hormones can increase plasma levels of corticosteroids and theophylline (by competing for metabolism), and can reduce effectiveness of warfarin and hypoglycemic agents (estrogens can increase certain clotting factors and binding proteins)

name: Plan B
dosage: Single-dose regimen: 1.5 mg orally as soon as possible within 72 hours after unprotected intercourse (the earlier, the better efficacy). Alternatively, older two-dose regimen: 0.75 mg twice (first dose ASAP, second dose 12 hours later)
indications: Emergency contraception to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse or known/suspected contraceptive failure; not intended for routine contraception
contraindications: Known or suspected pregnancy (not effective if implantation has already occurred); hypersensitivity to levonorgestrel; use in pre-pubertal children
side_effects: Menstrual changes (earlier, later, heavier or lighter bleeding at next period); nausea (occasionally vomiting – if vomiting within 2 hours of dose, may need to repeat dose); lower abdominal pain; fatigue; headache; dizziness; breast tenderness
mechanism_of_action: A high dose of progestin (levonorgestrel) that primarily works by preventing or delaying ovulation (inhibits the LH surge if given before ovulation). It may also cause changes in cervical mucus (impeding sperm transit) and alter the endometrial lining to reduce the likelihood of implantation. It is not effective once implantation has begun
drug_interactions: Enzyme inducers (like rifampin, carbamazepine, phenytoin, St. John's Wort) may reduce levonorgestrel levels, potentially decreasing efficacy (though given the urgency, one can't wait; consider doubling dose or using alternative EC like copper IUD in such cases); cyclosporine levels may be increased by levonorgestrel (progestins can inhibit cyclosporine metabolism); current use of ulipristal (another EC) within 5 days might make levonorgestrel less effective and vice versa (avoid using both in same cycle)

name: Proscar
dosage: 5 mg orally once daily (for BPH). For male pattern baldness (as Propecia formulation), 1 mg once daily
indications: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (to improve symptoms and reduce urinary retention risk; often in men with enlarged prostate); androgenetic alopecia (male pattern hair loss) in men (1 mg dose)
contraindications: Use in women when pregnant or potentially pregnant (can cause fetal genital abnormalities in male fetus; women of childbearing potential should not handle crushed tablets); hypersensitivity to finasteride; children
side_effects: Impotence (erectile dysfunction), decreased libido, ejaculation disorders; gynecomastia (rare); breast tenderness; in hair loss use, sexual side effects are usually at 1-2% and often transient, but some cases of persistent sexual dysfunction reported (rare "post-finasteride syndrome"); can reduce PSA levels by ~50% (which can mask prostate cancer detection)
mechanism_of_action: 5-alpha reductase inhibitor (type II isoenzyme); prevents conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). In the prostate, reduced DHT leads to shrinkage of the gland over months and improved BPH symptoms. In scalp, reduced DHT can slow hair loss and promote hair regrowth in androgen-sensitive follicles
drug_interactions: No major CYP-mediated interactions (not significantly via CYP system). Finasteride can theoretically reduce effectiveness of testosterone therapy since it blocks conversion to DHT, but in most patients on TRT that’s not clinically targeted. It may artificially lower PSA values (important when monitoring for prostate cancer); no significant pharmacokinetic interactions with common BPH meds (can be given with alpha-1 blockers; though combination may increase risk of hypotension if alpha blocker is not uroselective).

name: Flomax
dosage: 0.4 mg orally once daily approximately 30 minutes after the same meal each day (usually dinner). If inadequate response after 2-4 weeks, can increase to 0.8 mg once daily
indications: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (to improve urinary flow and reduce BPH symptoms by relaxing prostatic and bladder neck smooth muscle); off-label for facilitating passage of distal ureteral kidney stones (expulsive therapy)
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to tamsulosin (or components); history of angioedema with tamsulosin; caution in severe sulfa allergy (rare reports of allergy in sulfa patients); caution in orthostatic hypotension prone individuals
side_effects: Orthostatic hypotension, dizziness; headache; ejaculation failure or retrograde ejaculation; rhinitis (stuffy or runny nose); intraoperative floppy iris syndrome has been observed in cataract surgery patients who have taken tamsulosin
mechanism_of_action: Selective alpha-1A adrenergic receptor antagonist in the prostate and bladder neck. By blocking alpha-1A receptors, it causes smooth muscle relaxation in the prostate and bladder neck, thereby improving urine outflow in BPH without as much effect on systemic blood vessels (less alpha-1B activity, so less orthostatic hypotension relative to non-selective alpha blockers)
drug_interactions: Coadministration with other alpha-1 blockers (doxazosin, etc.) or antihypertensives can cause additive hypotension; strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (like ketoconazole) can raise tamsulosin levels (avoid or use with caution); PDE-5 inhibitors (sildenafil, etc.) can have additive blood pressure lowering; caution that if patient has cataract surgery planned, tamsulosin may cause floppy iris syndrome – need to inform ophthalmologist (not an interaction, but a surgical consideration)

name: Oxytocin
dosage: IV infusion for labor induction: start 0.5-1 milliunits/min, increase by 1-2 milliunits/min every 30-60 minutes until adequate uterine response (max typically 20 milliunits/min); for postpartum hemorrhage: 10-40 units in 1 L IV fluid at 250 mL/hr or 10 units IM after delivery of placenta
indications: Induction or augmentation of labor for medical reasons (e.g., post-term pregnancy, PROM with no labor, maternal conditions); control of postpartum uterine bleeding (postpartum hemorrhage prevention or treatment); to facilitate uterine contractions in management of incomplete or inevitable abortion
contraindications: Significant cephalopelvic disproportion; unfavorable fetal positions (e.g., transverse lie) that are an obstacle to delivery; fetal distress when delivery is not imminent; hyperactive or hypertonic uterus; contraindicated when vaginal delivery is contraindicated (e.g., placenta previa, vasa previa, prior classical C-section, active genital HSV)
side_effects: Excess uterine contractions (hyperstimulation) which can lead to fetal distress (due to decreased placental perfusion) or uterine rupture; hypotension (especially with rapid IV bolus); flushing; in high doses, water intoxication (oxytocin has slight ADH-like effect) leading to hyponatremia and seizures (with prolonged infusions at high rates); postpartum hemorrhage can occur if prolonged administration leads to uterine atony after discontinuation
mechanism_of_action: Oxytocin is a peptide hormone that stimulates oxytocin receptors on uterine smooth muscle, increasing intracellular calcium and causing uterine contractions. It also promotes milk ejection by contracting myoepithelial cells in the breast. By inducing rhythmic uterine contractions, it can initiate or strengthen labor and help compress uterine blood vessels postpartum to reduce bleeding
drug_interactions: Effects on uterine tone can be augmented by prostaglandins (like misoprostol or dinoprostone, often sequentially used for cervical ripening then oxytocin for induction); concurrent use with vasopressors can result in severe hypertension (oxytocin can cause vasodilation and reflex tachy which might interact unpredictably with vasopressors); magnesium sulfate (as in preeclampsia) may antagonize oxytocin's uterotonic effect (since magnesium relaxes uterine muscle)

name: Viagra
dosage: 50 mg orally as needed ~1 hour before sexual activity (range 25-100 mg; max once daily). Adjust dose based on efficacy and tolerability (25 mg in elderly or with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors)
indications: Erectile dysfunction; pulmonary arterial hypertension (separate brand Revatio at different dosing regimen)
contraindications: Concurrent use of nitrates in any form (e.g., nitroglycerin, isosorbide dinitrate) due to risk of severe hypotension​:contentReference[oaicite:34]{index=34}; concomitant use with riociguat (soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator); hypersensitivity to sildenafil
side_effects: Headache, flushing, dyspepsia, nasal congestion; visual disturbances (blue-tinged vision or increased sensitivity to light) – related to PDE6 inhibition in retina; dizziness; hypotension (especially with nitrates); in rare cases, non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION) has been reported; priapism (prolonged erection) is rare but serious
mechanism_of_action: Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor: in the corpus cavernosum, sexual stimulation causes nitric oxide release, which increases cGMP leading to smooth muscle relaxation and inflow of blood. Sildenafil blocks PDE5 from degrading cGMP, thereby enhancing the natural erectile response to sexual stimulation. It has minimal effect in absence of sexual arousal
drug_interactions: Absolutely contraindicated with nitrates (nitroglycerin, isosorbide) as it can cause life-threatening hypotension​:contentReference[oaicite:35]{index=35}; caution with alpha-blockers (can lead to hypotension—use lowest doses and separate timing); potent CYP3A4 inhibitors (e.g., ketoconazole, ritonavir) increase sildenafil levels (start with 25 mg dose); alcohol can increase risk of orthostatic hypotension; other PDE5 inhibitors or riociguat combination would greatly amplify hypotension (avoid combination)

name: Cialis
dosage: For erectile dysfunction: 10 mg orally before anticipated sexual activity (range 5-20 mg) or 2.5-5 mg once daily without regard to timing of sexual activity. For BPH: 5 mg once daily. (In renal/hepatic impairment, dose adjustments or avoidance as needed.)
indications: Erectile dysfunction; benign prostatic hyperplasia (to improve urinary symptoms); ED + BPH concomitantly; pulmonary arterial hypertension (as Adcirca brand, 40 mg once daily)
contraindications: Concurrent use of organic nitrates (risk of severe hypotension)​:contentReference[oaicite:36]{index=36}; concomitant use of guanylate cyclase stimulators like riociguat; hypersensitivity to tadalafil
side_effects: Headache, flushing, dyspepsia, nasal congestion, back pain or myalgia (unique-ish to tadalafil, possibly due to PDE11 inhibition in muscle); dizziness; hypotension; rarely, visual disturbance (but less PDE6 effect than sildenafil); hearing loss (rare); priapism (rare)
mechanism_of_action: PDE5 inhibitor: enhances erectile function by inhibiting breakdown of cGMP in corpus cavernosum during sexual stimulation, thus promoting smooth muscle relaxation and inflow of blood. Tadalafil has a longer duration of action (half-life ~17.5 hours, up to 36-hour effect) compared to sildenafil. In BPH, mechanism may involve relaxation of smooth muscle in prostate and bladder. In pulmonary hypertension, it relaxes pulmonary vasculature
drug_interactions: Contraindicated with nitrates (serious hypotension)​:contentReference[oaicite:37]{index=37}; caution with alpha-1 blockers (especially non-selective like doxazosin) due to blood pressure drop; potent CYP3A4 inhibitors (clarithromycin, itraconazole) increase tadalafil levels (consider dose reduction or avoid daily dosing >2.5 mg); rifampin or other inducers lower tadalafil levels; alcohol can add to hypotensive effect; since effects last longer, nitrates should be avoided for at least 48 hours after tadalafil use (versus 24h for sildenafil)

name: Proventil
dosage: Inhaler: 2 puffs (90 mcg each puff) every 4-6 hours as needed for bronchospasm. Nebulizer: 2.5 mg in 3 mL of saline via nebulization 3-4 times daily as needed. Exercise-induced bronchospasm: 2 puffs 15 minutes before exercise
indications: Bronchospasm in patients with reversible obstructive airway disease (asthma, COPD) for quick relief (rescue inhaler); prevention of exercise-induced bronchospasm
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to albuterol or any components (e.g., severe milk protein allergy in some dry powder inhalers that contain lactose); caution in patients with severe cardiac disease (can cause tachyarrhythmias)
side_effects: Tremor, nervousness, headache; tachycardia, palpitations; hypokalemia (transient); throat irritation; at high doses, can cause hyperglycemia; less common: paradoxical bronchospasm (rare, if formulation irritates airway); insomnia
mechanism_of_action: Short-acting beta-2 adrenergic receptor agonist (SABA); stimulates beta-2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle, resulting in relaxation and bronchodilation. Onset of action is rapid (within minutes), providing quick relief of bronchospasm
drug_interactions: Other sympathomimetics (additive stimulation); beta-blockers can reduce albuterol's effect or precipitate bronchospasm (nonselective beta-blockers especially, so avoid in asthma patients if possible)​:contentReference[oaicite:38]{index=38}; diuretics (loop/thiazide) can potentiate hypokalemia; MAO inhibitors or tricyclic antidepressants theoretically may potentiate albuterol's vascular effects (use with caution within 2 weeks of such agents); inhaled anesthetics like halothane can increase risk of arrhythmias with albuterol (caution if on high doses around time of anesthesia)

name: Spiriva
dosage: Inhale contents of one 18 mcg capsule via HandiHaler device once daily (for COPD maintenance), or two inhalations of the Respimat 2.5 mcg (total 5 mcg) once daily; for asthma maintenance (Respimat): two inhalations of 1.25 mcg (total 2.5 mcg) once daily
indications: Maintenance treatment of bronchospasm associated with COPD (including chronic bronchitis and emphysema); reducing COPD exacerbations; also as add-on maintenance treatment for asthma in patients ≥6 years (using the Respimat formulation)
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to tiotropium or ipratropium or other atropine-like (anticholinergic) agents; not for acute bronchospasm (rescue use)
side_effects: Dry mouth (common); pharyngitis, sinusitis; upper respiratory infection; constipation, urinary retention (especially in men with BPH); blurred vision if powder gets in eyes; rarely, paradoxical bronchospasm; potential anticholinergic systemic effects at high doses or susceptible individuals
mechanism_of_action: Long-acting anticholinergic (antimuscarinic) bronchodilator; selectively antagonizes M3 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle, leading to relaxation and bronchodilation. Duration of action ~24 hours, so suitable for once-daily maintenance in COPD/asthma
drug_interactions: Additive anticholinergic effects with other anticholinergic drugs (e.g., atropine, ipratropium – avoid duplicate therapy); caution if used with other drugs that cause urinary retention or constipation (like first-gen antihistamines) due to additive side effects; no significant CYP interactions since tiotropium is poorly absorbed systemically; co-administration with beta-agonists or inhaled corticosteroids is complementary (often used together in COPD combo regimens)

name: Advair Diskus
dosage: One inhalation of 250/50 (fluticasone 250 mcg / salmeterol 50 mcg) twice daily approximately 12 hours apart for COPD maintenance (higher strengths for asthma: available 100/50, 250/50, 500/50 mcg; dose depends on asthma severity). Do not exceed 2 inhalations (doses) in 24 hours
indications: Asthma maintenance treatment (for patients not adequately controlled on inhaled corticosteroids alone or whose disease warrants combination therapy); maintenance treatment of COPD (chronic bronchitis and/or emphysema) to reduce exacerbations and improve lung function
contraindications: Primary treatment of status asthmaticus or acute asthma/COPD exacerbations (not a rescue inhaler); severe hypersensitivity to milk proteins (Diskus contains lactose); known hypersensitivity to fluticasone or salmeterol
side_effects: Hoarseness, oral candidiasis (thrush) from ICS component; cough; headache; upper respiratory tract infection; mild tremor or palpitations (LABA component); potential systemic steroid effects if high dose (adrenal suppression, growth deceleration in children, bone density loss) though low; LABA-related rare effects: tachycardia, QT prolongation; black box warning (historical for LABAs in asthma without ICS, but combination mitigates risk)
mechanism_of_action: Combination of an inhaled corticosteroid (fluticasone) and a long-acting beta-2 agonist (salmeterol). Fluticasone propionate reduces inflammation in the airways by binding glucocorticoid receptors (reducing inflammatory mediator release, immune cell recruitment). Salmeterol stimulates beta-2 receptors causing prolonged bronchodilation (about 12 hours)​:contentReference[oaicite:39]{index=39}. Together they address both inflammation and bronchoconstriction in asthma/COPD
drug_interactions: Systemic ketoconazole or other potent CYP3A4 inhibitors can increase systemic fluticasone (raising risk of systemic steroid effects) and salmeterol (raising risk of cardiovascular side effects); avoid non-selective beta-blockers (they antagonize salmeterol effects and can precipitate bronchospasm); caution with other long-acting sympathomimetics (to avoid overdose of beta agonist); diuretics that cause hypokalemia + salmeterol can potentiate ECG changes or arrhythmia risk (due to beta-agonist induced shifts in K+); no significant interaction with other inhaled drugs like tiotropium aside from additive therapeutic benefit

name: Singulair
dosage: 10 mg orally once daily in the evening for adults (age ≥15) for asthma or allergic rhinitis; ages 6-14: 5 mg chewable once daily; ages 2-5: 4 mg chewable once daily (or granules 4 mg for 12-23 months in asthma). For exercise-induced bronchoconstriction: 10 mg at least 2 hours before exercise (and not again within 24h)
indications: Maintenance treatment of asthma (mild persistent to moderate) as add-on therapy; prevention of exercise-induced bronchospasm; relief of symptoms of seasonal or perennial allergic rhinitis
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to montelukast; not indicated for acute asthma attacks/status asthmaticus
side_effects: Generally well tolerated. Possible: headache, abdominal pain, flu-like symptoms. Postmarketing reports (rare): neuropsychiatric effects (agitation, aggression, depression, sleep disturbances, suicidal thoughts)​:contentReference[oaicite:40]{index=40}— recently highlighted; Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) in asthmatics typically when tapering steroids and on leukotriene modifiers (rare); elevated liver enzymes (rare)
mechanism_of_action: Leukotriene receptor antagonist; selectively blocks cysteinyl leukotriene (CysLT1) receptors in the airways and bronchial smooth muscle, preventing leukotriene D4 and related leukotrienes from exerting bronchoconstrictor and pro-inflammatory effects. Reduces bronchospasm, inflammation, and mucus secretion associated with leukotriene activity in asthma and allergic rhinitis
drug_interactions: Metabolized by CYP3A4/2C9: enzyme inducers like rifampin or carbamazepine can modestly reduce montelukast levels (may not be clinically significant enough to adjust dose); gemfibrozil (strong 2C8 inhibitor) can increase montelukast levels ~4.5-fold, but generally no dose adjustment recommended; montelukast may reduce the need for beta-agonists (additive effect beneficial); no major contraindicated interactions. Caution advised combining with other neuropsychiatric drugs until more is known about NPS effects

name: Deltasone
dosage: Dosage varies widely by condition: e.g., 5-60 mg orally once daily (or divided) for many inflammatory conditions. Taper as required for long-term use. (For acute asthma exacerbation: often 40-60 mg daily for 5-10 days; for autoimmune flares may start higher and taper.) Use lowest effective dose for chronic therapy
indications: A broad range of inflammatory, allergic, autoimmune disorders (e.g., asthma exacerbations, rheumatoid arthritis, lupus); graft-versus-host disease prophylaxis; acute transplant rejection; many dermatologic conditions; palliative management of some leukemias/lymphomas; adrenal insufficiency (as a glucocorticoid replacement in combination with mineralocorticoid)
contraindications: Systemic fungal infections (risk of exacerbating infection); administration of live or live-attenuated vaccines if on immunosuppressive doses; hypersensitivity to prednisone. Caution in active serious infections (unless treating infection-related inflammation), GI ulcers, diabetes, osteoporosis, psychiatric illness
side_effects: Short term: insomnia, mood changes (euphoria, depression), hyperglycemia, increased appetite, fluid retention, GI irritation. Long term: Cushingoid appearance (moon face, buffalo hump), weight gain, osteoporosis, muscle wasting, hypertension, peptic ulcers, cataracts, glaucoma, immunosuppression leading to infection risk, adrenal suppression (leading to secondary adrenal insufficiency on withdrawal), skin thinning, striae, acne. Can also cause growth suppression in children
mechanism_of_action: Synthetic glucocorticoid; prednisone is a prodrug converted to prednisolone in the liver. It binds to glucocorticoid receptors, modifying gene expression and suppressing the immune response and inflammation: it decreases production of inflammatory mediators (cytokines, prostaglandins, leukotrienes) and inhibits migration of leukocytes, stabilizes lysosomal membranes, and decreases capillary permeability
drug_interactions: Many interactions: it is a CYP3A4 substrate, so inducers (rifampin, phenytoin, etc.) can lower levels, and inhibitors (ketoconazole, clarithromycin) can increase levels; additive GI ulcer risk with NSAIDs; can reduce effect of antidiabetic medications (raises blood sugar); enhances potassium loss with diuretics (leading to hypokalemia); can reduce immune response to vaccines (and increase risk of dissemination with live vaccines); may reduce serum levels of isoniazid; birth control pills can increase steroid levels; prednisone can increase metabolism of HIV protease inhibitors (and vice versa) in complex ways

name: Decadron
dosage: Dose depends on disease: e.g., 0.5-9 mg/day orally divided (high potency, long acting). For cerebral edema: 10 mg IV stat, then 4 mg IM/IV every 6 hours until symptoms subside. For chemotherapy antiemetic prophylaxis, e.g., 8-20 mg IV before chemo. Taper if used long-term
indications: Inflammatory and autoimmune conditions (similar to other corticosteroids, especially when water retention must be minimized); cerebral edema (associated with tumors, altitude sickness); adjunct in bacterial meningitis; antiemetic in chemotherapy; diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome (dexamethasone suppression test); prevention of respiratory distress syndrome in preterm labor (antenatal steroid, often betamethasone used, but dex is alternative)
contraindications: Systemic fungal infections; live virus vaccines in patients receiving immunosuppressive doses; hypersensitivity. Same precautions as other systemic corticosteroids regarding active infections, GI ulceration, etc.
side_effects: Similar to prednisone, though dexamethasone lacks significant mineralocorticoid activity: Insomnia, mood changes, hyperglycemia, GI irritation acutely. Chronic use: Cushingoid features, adrenal suppression, osteoporosis, muscle wasting, infections, cataracts, growth suppression in children, etc. Dexamethasone can cause even more pronounced psychiatric disturbances in some cases (like psychosis) due to potency
mechanism_of_action: Long-acting glucocorticoid (approximately 25x more potent anti-inflammatory than hydrocortisone, with negligible mineralocorticoid effect). It binds glucocorticoid receptors leading to altered transcription and suppression of inflammation and immune response (decreased leukocyte migration, stabilization of lysosomes, reduced cytokines, etc.)
drug_interactions: CYP3A4 substrate: inducers (like rifampin, phenytoin) can decrease levels; inhibitors (like itraconazole) can increase levels; can reduce plasma concentrations of medications like phenytoin or salicylates (by increasing metabolism or clearance); additive hypokalemia with diuretics or amphotericin B; can reduce efficacy of antidiabetic drugs (raise glucose); risk of tendon rupture with concurrent quinolones may be increased (both can affect tendons). Also, dexamethasone is sometimes used to intentionally interact (like it can increase metabolism of some chemo drugs to reduce toxicity, etc.)

name: Humira
dosage: 40 mg subcutaneously every other week (for rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, plaque psoriasis, etc.). Some conditions like hidradenitis suppurativa use 160 mg week 0, 80 mg week 2, then 40 mg weekly. For uveitis or Crohn’s, often 80 mg loading then 40 mg every other week. Dosing varies by indication and weight (pediatric Crohn's different).
indications: Rheumatoid arthritis (moderate to severe, often with methotrexate); psoriatic arthritis; ankylosing spondylitis; moderate to severe Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis; plaque psoriasis; juvenile idiopathic arthritis; hidradenitis suppurativa; non-infectious uveitis (intermediate, posterior, and panuveitis)
contraindications: Active serious infections (sepsis, TB, opportunistic infections); known hypersensitivity to adalimumab; not to be used in patients with demyelinating diseases or heart failure without caution (TNF blockers can exacerbate MS, and severe CHF)
side_effects: Injection site reactions (redness, itching, pain); upper respiratory and sinus infections; headache, rash. Serious: increased risk of serious infections (TB, fungal, other opportunistic)​:contentReference[oaicite:41]{index=41}; reactivation of hepatitis B; rare demyelinating disease; neutropenia; lupus-like syndrome; malignancies including lymphoma (especially in children/young adults) have been reported with TNF blockers; heart failure worsening; psoriasis paradoxically (rarely new or worsening)
mechanism_of_action: Recombinant human monoclonal antibody against tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-α). It binds TNF-α and prevents it from activating TNF receptors, thereby reducing inflammation and immune response that TNF mediates. TNF-α is a key cytokine in inflammatory conditions, so blocking it ameliorates diseases like RA, IBD, psoriasis
drug_interactions: Should not be used with other biologic anti-TNF or immunosuppressants like anakinra or abatacept (due to increased risk of infections or neutropenia); live vaccines should be avoided during therapy and shortly after (diminished immune response and infection risk from live agent); can be combined carefully with methotrexate (which is common in RA and can reduce anti-drug antibody formation); no significant cytochrome interactions (it's a protein). Monitor if used with other immunosuppressive or myelosuppressive therapies due to additive effects on infection risk

name: Remicade
dosage: 5 mg/kg IV at 0, 2, and 6 weeks, then every 8 weeks for maintenance (for Crohn's, ulcerative colitis, plaque psoriasis, psoriatic arthritis, RA with MTX, and ankylosing spondylitis, though RA is 3 mg/kg q8wk). Dose can be increased to 10 mg/kg or interval shortened in some refractory cases. Infuse over at least 2 hours (can shorten in some cases on stable dosing). Pre-medicate if prior infusion reactions
indications: Moderate to severe Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis (induction and maintenance of remission); rheumatoid arthritis (in combination with methotrexate) if inadequate response to other therapies; psoriatic arthritis; plaque psoriasis (moderate-severe); ankylosing spondylitis; also off-label for some refractory cases of Behcet's, uveitis, etc.
contraindications: Doses >5 mg/kg in moderate-severe heart failure (infliximab can worsen CHF); hypersensitivity to infliximab or murine proteins (chimeric antibody ~25% mouse); active serious infection (including TB, sepsis, opportunistic infections)
side_effects: Infusion reactions (fever, chills, pruritus, hypotension or even anaphylaxis especially with antibodies formed; can be acute or delayed serum sickness-like); increased risk of serious infections (TB, fungal, bacterial)​:contentReference[oaicite:42]{index=42}; reactivation of latent TB or HBV; development of autoantibodies and lupus-like syndrome (rare); headache, abdominal pain; increased risk of malignancies (lymphomas and skin cancers reported); heart failure exacerbation; formation of anti-drug antibodies (which can reduce efficacy and increase infusion reactions, mitigated by concurrent MTX)
mechanism_of_action: Chimeric (human-murine) IgG1 monoclonal antibody that binds soluble and transmembrane forms of TNF-α, neutralizing its activity. By blocking TNF-α, a key pro-inflammatory cytokine, it reduces inflammation and alters immune response in autoimmune diseases like RA and IBD. It can also cause lysis of cells expressing TNF (with complement) since it's IgG1
drug_interactions: Avoid concurrent use with other biologic immunosuppressants such as anakinra or abatacept (due to increased risk of infections); live vaccines should not be given concurrently (impaired immune response and infection risk); methotrexate is often co-administered and actually beneficial (reduces anti-infliximab antibody formation and increases efficacy). If used with other immunosuppressants (e.g., azathioprine in IBD), watch for additive infection risk. No significant P450 interactions (though TNF blockade might normalize some p450 activity suppressed by high cytokine states, potentially lowering drug levels of some medications when disease goes into remission, per a theoretical model)

name: Neoral
dosage: Transplant: Initial ~5-6 mg/kg/day oral given in 2 divided doses starting prior to transplant, adjust to target trough levels (100-400 ng/mL depending on assay and time post-transplant, varies by organ/protocol). Maintenance usually 3-5 mg/kg/day. For RA/psoriasis: ~2.5 mg/kg/day initially, can increase to 4 mg/kg/day divided. (Sandimmune and Neoral not bioequivalent; Neoral has improved absorption). IV dose is ~1/3 of oral dose
indications: Prophylaxis of organ rejection in kidney, liver, heart transplants (used with other immunosuppressants); treatment of chronic rejection in patients previously treated with other immunosuppressants; rheumatoid arthritis (severe, refractory cases); severe psoriasis (in non-immunocompromised adults); also used in other off-label immune conditions (e.g., nephrotic syndrome, uveitis)
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to cyclosporine or its excipients (e.g., Cremophor in IV); RA/psoriasis patients with uncontrolled hypertension, malignancies, or serious infections should not receive; use of concomitant UVA therapy in psoriasis (increases skin cancer risk further). Avoid use with other calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus) simultaneously. Neoral specifically: no specific absolute contras beyond above, but careful in renal dysfunction (dosing adjustments)
side_effects: Nephrotoxicity (dose-dependent, common; manifests as elevated creatinine, reduced GFR); hypertension (common, often requiring treatment); tremor, headache; hirsutism; gingival hyperplasia; hyperlipidemia; nausea; increased risk of infections; hepatotoxicity; lymphoproliferative disorders and other malignancies (due to immunosuppression)​:contentReference[oaicite:43]{index=43}; burning sensation in hands/feet (rare); electrolyte disturbances (hyperkalemia, hypomagnesemia). Many side effects are dose- or trough-related
mechanism_of_action: Calcineurin inhibitor immunosuppressant. Cyclosporine binds to cyclophilin in T-lymphocytes, and this complex inhibits calcineurin, which normally activates T-cell transcription of IL-2 and other cytokines. Thus, cyclosporine selectively inhibits T-lymphocyte activation (especially helper T cells) and proliferation, preventing immune responses like graft rejection. It does not significantly suppress bone marrow (more so suppresses cell-mediated immunity)
drug_interactions: Cyclosporine is a CYP3A4 and P-gp substrate (also an inhibitor). Many interactions: CYP3A4 inhibitors (ketoconazole, diltiazem, erythromycin, grapefruit juice) can raise cyclosporine levels (risk toxicity); CYP3A4 inducers (rifampin, phenytoin, St. John's Wort) lower levels (risk rejection); concomitant nephrotoxic drugs (NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, amphotericin) potentiate renal damage; synergistic immunosuppression with other agents (e.g., increased risk of PML with natalizumab, etc.); cyclosporine can increase levels of statins (risk rhabdo; simvastatin dose limit 10 mg with CSA) and digoxin (by P-gp inhibition)​:contentReference[oaicite:44]{index=44}; also increases colchicine levels (more toxicity); tacrolimus co-use is contraindicated (excess nephrotoxicity); live vaccines efficacy reduced; careful with potassium-sparing diuretics (hyperkalemia risk increased)

name: Prograf
dosage: Initial for transplant: 0.1-0.2 mg/kg/day orally divided q12h (higher end for thoracic, lower for kidney) starting immediately post-op. Adjust to trough levels (often 5-15 ng/mL target depending on time post-transplant and center). IV dosing ~1/3 of oral (continuous infusion or q12h injection). Topical form (Protopic) used for eczema: apply thinly twice daily (0.03% or 0.1%)
indications: Prophylaxis of organ rejection in allogeneic kidney, liver, heart transplant (used with other immunosuppressants); topical tacrolimus for moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis when other treatments are inadvisable
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to tacrolimus or its formulation (IV form contains castor oil derivative which can cause anaphylaxis - contraindicated if sensitivity); should not be used in transplant patients without proper monitoring and concomitant immunosuppression; caution in patients with QT prolongation risk (tacrolimus may prolong QT, especially with other drugs)
side_effects: Nephrotoxicity (very common; similar to cyclosporine mechanism); neurotoxicity (tremor, headache, neuropathy, even seizures at high levels); hypertension; hyperglycemia/new-onset diabetes (tacrolimus more diabetogenic than cyclosporine); infections; malignancies (lymphoma, skin cancers) due to immunosuppression​:contentReference[oaicite:45]{index=45}; GI upset; electrolyte disturbances (hyperkalemia, hypomagnesemia); less hirsutism or gingival hyperplasia than cyclosporine; alopecia (some patients)
mechanism_of_action: Calcineurin inhibitor immunosuppressant. Tacrolimus binds to FKBP-12 (FK506 binding protein) in T cells, and this complex inhibits calcineurin phosphatase, thus preventing activation of NFAT and transcription of IL-2 and other cytokines.
