The result is potent inhibition of T-lymphocyte activation and proliferation, preventing graft rejection. Topically, it inhibits local T cell-mediated inflammation in skin
drug_interactions: Similar to cyclosporine but tacrolimus is even more sensitive to CYP3A4 changes: CYP3A4 inhibitors (azole antifungals, macrolides like clarithromycin, diltiazem, verapamil, protease inhibitors, grapefruit) can drastically increase tacrolimus levels (toxicity risk) - require dose reduction or avoidance; inducers (rifampin, phenytoin, St. John's Wort) can cause subtherapeutic levels (rejection risk); additive nephrotoxicity with NSAIDs, amphotericin, aminoglycosides; avoid other calcineurin inhibitors; tacrolimus may increase levels of sirolimus if used together (and vice versa, they often separate dosing or avoid combination to reduce toxicity); QT prolonging drugs in combination with tacro might increase arrhythmia risk; live vaccines less effective; careful with potassium-sparing diuretics (hyperkalemia). Note: tacrolimus absorption decreased by magnesium/aluminum antacids if taken simultaneously

name: CellCept
dosage: 1 g orally or IV twice daily (2 g/day) for kidney transplant prophylaxis (1.5 g BID for heart or liver transplant often). Adjust dose or frequency if hematologic side effects. Mycophenolic acid (Myfortic) is 720 mg BID ~equivalent to 1 g MMF BID. Take on empty stomach if possible
indications: Prophylaxis of organ rejection in kidney, heart, or liver transplant (usually in combination with calcineurin inhibitor and corticosteroid); off-label for lupus nephritis, other immune-mediated diseases (though not FDA-approved for those, it's often used)
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to mycophenolate; pregnancy (contraindicated due to high teratogenic risk - REMS program, requires negative tests and contraception)​:contentReference[oaicite:46]{index=46}; breastfeeding (excreted in milk); caution in patients with active serious infections due to immunosuppression
side_effects: GI upset (nausea, diarrhea, gastritis are common dose-limiting side effects); bone marrow suppression (leukopenia, anemia, thrombocytopenia) dose-related; increased risk of infections (viral, bacterial, fungal) and sepsis; increased risk of lymphomas and skin malignancies (immunosuppression-related); teratogenicity (congenital malformations, pregnancy loss); less nephrotoxic or neurotoxic than calcineurin inhibitors; can cause hypertension; elevated cholesterol
mechanism_of_action: Antiproliferative immunosuppressant: Mycophenolate is a prodrug converted to mycophenolic acid, which reversibly inhibits inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH) in purine synthesis. This particularly affects lymphocytes (T and B cells) because they rely on the de novo purine (guanine) synthesis pathway more than salvage. Thus it selectively inhibits lymphocyte proliferation and function (like antibody formation) and prevents rejection
drug_interactions: Antacids or supplements containing aluminum or magnesium hydroxide can reduce MMF absorption (separate dosing); cholestyramine significantly reduces mycophenolate levels (avoid if possible); acyclovir/ganciclovir can compete for renal tubular secretion, increasing levels of both (monitor for toxicity); live vaccines may be less effective and potentially risky; tacrolimus may increase MMF levels by impairing GI motility (variably); rifampin can decrease mycophenolate levels (avoid or monitor); mycophenolate may decrease efficacy of oral contraceptives (some evidence suggests it might, plus MMF is contraindicated in pregnancy anyway)​:contentReference[oaicite:47]{index=47}

name: Imuran
dosage: 1-3 mg/kg/day orally (50-150 mg daily typical) for maintenance immunosuppression in transplant or autoimmune disease; in renal transplant often start ~3-5 mg/kg/day initially then maintenance ~1-3 mg/kg. Adjust dose to lowest effective, and reduce if leukopenia. TPMT deficiency patients need dose reduction. Also available IV in equivalent dosing
indications: Prevention of organ transplant rejection (now less common due to MMF but still used); rheumatoid arthritis (severe cases); off-label in many autoimmune conditions: systemic lupus (especially lupus nephritis), inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's, UC maintenance), autoimmune hepatitis, etc.
contraindications: Pregnancy is not absolute contra (categorized D: risk but benefit may outweigh in transplants or lupus, etc.); hypersensitivity to azathioprine; prior alkylating therapy increases risk of malignancy with AZA (caution); patients with TPMT (thiopurine methyltransferase) deficiency at high risk of severe myelosuppression—should avoid or drastically reduce dose
side_effects: Bone marrow suppression (leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, anemia) dose-dependent and can be severe especially if TPMT deficient​:contentReference[oaicite:48]{index=48}; increased susceptibility to infections; nausea, vomiting (common initial); hepatotoxicity (elevated LFTs, rare veno-occlusive disease); pancreatitis (idiosyncratic ~3-5% especially in IBD patients); increased risk of malignancies (lymphomas, skin cancers) especially with long-term use; alopecia (occasionally); opportunistic infections like PML (rare)
mechanism_of_action: Prodrug of 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP). It is a purine analog that gets incorporated into DNA and RNA, and also inhibits purine synthesis (via conversion to fraudulent nucleotides like thio-GTP, thio-dGTP). This results in inhibition of lymphocyte proliferation (T and B cells) as they rapidly divide and rely on purine synthesis. It is cytotoxic to proliferating cells, particularly affecting immune cells, thus providing immunosuppressive effects
drug_interactions: Allopurinol or febuxostat (xanthine oxidase inhibitors) dramatically increase 6-MP/azathioprine levels by blocking their metabolism, leading to severe toxicity; dose of AZA must be reduced to ~25% if allopurinol is used​:contentReference[oaicite:49]{index=49}; aminosalicylates (mesalamine, sulfasalazine) can also inhibit TPMT slightly, increasing AZA toxicity risk; ACE inhibitors combined with AZA can increase risk of anemia/leukopenia (some reports); warfarin effect may be reduced by AZA; co-use with other myelosuppressives (like TMP-SMX) can have additive leukopenia; live vaccines should be avoided; concurrent tacrolimus or ganciclovir can further suppress marrow or raise infection risk (monitor counts closely)

name: Trexall
dosage: For rheumatoid arthritis or psoriasis: 7.5-15 mg once weekly (oral or SC/IM), can increase to 20-25 mg weekly if needed/tolerated (give folic acid supplement to reduce side effects). For chemotherapy (e.g., leukemia): dosing varies widely, can be much higher and daily for short cycles with leucovorin rescue. For ectopic pregnancy: 50 mg/m^2 IM single dose (or multiple dose protocols)
indications: Rheumatoid arthritis (moderate-severe, as a DMARD); psoriasis (severe, recalcitrant); certain cancers: acute lymphoblastic leukemia (maintenance), trophoblastic neoplasms (choriocarcinoma), lymphomas, osteosarcoma, etc.; Crohn's disease (off-label maintenance); ectopic pregnancy (medical management); other autoimmune diseases off-label (dermatomyositis, systemic lupus, etc.)
contraindications: Pregnancy (teratogenic, abortifacient)​:contentReference[oaicite:50]{index=50}; breastfeeding; alcoholism or chronic liver disease (due to hepatotoxicity risk); pre-existing blood dyscrasias (like bone marrow hypoplasia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia) in non-malignant use; immunodeficiency (for rheumatoid/psoriasis use); during significant infections
side_effects: Stomatitis (oral ulcers), nausea, GI upset; elevated liver enzymes, hepatotoxicity (especially long-term, in psoriasis/RA monitor LFTs, risk of cirrhosis); bone marrow suppression (leukopenia, anemia, thrombocytopenia) dose-dependent; infection risk; pulmonary toxicity (pneumonitis) which can be idiosyncratic; rash, photosensitivity; alopecia; folate deficiency (hence folic acid supplementation recommended in low-dose therapy); in high-dose chemo, severe toxicities (mucositis, kidney injury, etc. mitigate with leucovorin rescue). Also can cause fatigue and malaise on dose days. Long-term low-dose can cause nodulosis or other weird effects in RA. Tumor lysis syndrome if treating malignancy with high tumor burden
mechanism_of_action: Folate antimetabolite that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, thereby preventing formation of tetrahydrofolate, which is necessary for purine and thymidine synthesis. In cancer, this leads to inhibition of DNA synthesis and cell replication, especially in rapidly dividing cells. In rheumatoid arthritis and psoriasis, the mechanism is partly due to anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects (e.g., promotes adenosine release, affects cytokine production) beyond the antiproliferative effect on immune cells
drug_interactions: Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole can significantly increase methotrexate toxicity (both inhibit DHFR, plus TMP can reduce MTX clearance)​:contentReference[oaicite:51]{index=51}; NSAIDs and penicillins can reduce renal elimination of MTX (especially high-dose) and increase toxicity; loop diuretics may elevate MTX levels; other folate depleting drugs increase toxicity; live vaccines should be avoided; leucovorin (folinic acid) rescues normal cells from MTX (used intentionally in high-dose regimens, but if given inadvertently in RA dosing would reduce efficacy); cyclosporine with MTX can increase toxicity of both; alcohol should be avoided due to liver risk; proton pump inhibitors can affect renal elimination of MTX (especially high dose IV) causing increased levels; highly protein-bound drugs like salicylates or phenytoin can displace MTX from albumin and increase active levels

name: Taxol
dosage: Varies by regimen/cancer: e.g., for ovarian cancer: 175 mg/m^2 IV over 3 hours every 3 weeks; for breast cancer (adjuvant) often 80 mg/m^2 IV weekly ×12; requires premedication (dexamethasone, H1 and H2 blockers) to prevent hypersensitivity. Dose adjustments for neutropenia or neuropathy
indications: Various cancers: ovarian carcinoma (first-line and recurrent); breast cancer (adjuvant or metastatic); non-small cell and small cell lung cancer; AIDS-related Kaposi's sarcoma; off-label for others like pancreatic (in combo nab-paclitaxel), etc. It's a broad-spectrum cytotoxic agent often used in solid tumors
contraindications: Neutrophils <1500 cells/µL (for solid tumor therapy, hold until counts recover); severe hypersensitivity to paclitaxel or Cremophor EL (castor oil derivative solvent) – patients with severe reaction should not be re-challenged; pregnancy (teratogenic/fetal toxic)
side_effects: Neutropenia (dose-limiting, can be severe), leukopenia; peripheral neuropathy (often sensory, cumulative dose dependent); alopecia (often total body hair loss); nausea, vomiting (mild to moderate); hypersensitivity reactions (due to Cremophor solvent, can be severe - hence premedication is required); mucositis; arthralgias/myalgias a few days after infusion; bradycardia or heart block (during infusion, usually asymptomatic); hepatic toxicity (elevated LFTs); extravasation can cause tissue injury (though it's an irritant more than vesicant). Also risk of cumulative bone marrow suppression causing anemia/thrombocytopenia
mechanism_of_action: Paclitaxel is a plant-derived antineoplastic (from yew tree). It stabilizes polymerized microtubules and prevents their depolymerization, thereby disrupting the normal dynamic reorganization of microtubule network required for mitosis. This causes cell cycle arrest in metaphase and eventual apoptotic cell death. Essentially, it 'freezes' microtubules in place, inhibiting mitosis
drug_interactions: Drugs that inhibit CYP2C8 or CYP3A4 can affect paclitaxel clearance (e.g., ketoconazole can increase levels; rifampin can decrease levels); dosing sequence with cisplatin: if used together, give paclitaxel *before* cisplatin, because cisplatin can reduce paclitaxel clearance leading to increased toxicity​:contentReference[oaicite:52]{index=52}; doxorubicin clearance is decreased by paclitaxel (if given closely, so in combos like AC->T, sequence and timing matter); paclitaxel can increase toxicity of radiation therapy if given concurrently (radiosensitizer); avoid live vaccines (chemo-induced immunosuppression). Grapefruit juice may increase levels (CYP3A4 inhib). Clozapine additive risk for agranulocytosis (rare, but both suppress bone marrow).

name: Avastin
dosage: Typically 5-15 mg/kg IV every 2 or 3 weeks depending on cancer type (e.g., 5 mg/kg q2w for metastatic colorectal with 5-FU, or 15 mg/kg q3w for lung cancer). For glioblastoma, 10 mg/kg q2w. Administer as IV infusion over 30-90 minutes (depending on dose and cycle number). Continue until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity
indications: Metastatic colorectal cancer (with chemotherapy); non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer (with carboplatin/paclitaxel); metastatic renal cell carcinoma (with interferon alfa); recurrent glioblastoma (single agent); cervical cancer (persistent/recurrent/metastatic, with chemo); ovarian/fallopian tube, or peritoneal cancer (with chemo for platinum-resistant or as maintenance in platinum-sensitive); also off-label in others. Also used intravitreally (off-label) for neovascular age-related macular degeneration, though not intravenous route for that
contraindications: Serious hemorrhage or recent hemoptysis in lung cancer (≥2.5 mL fresh blood); recent major surgery (within 28 days) or upcoming surgery (hold bevacizumab due to wound healing complications); uncontrolled hypertension; hypersensitivity to bevacizumab or Chinese hamster ovary cell products
side_effects: Hypertension (common, may need management); proteinuria (can lead to nephrotic syndrome, monitor urine protein); arterial thromboembolic events (stroke, MI); bleeding (mucosal, epistaxis common, but serious hemorrhage can occur especially pulmonary hemorrhage in lung cancer); wound healing complications (dehiscence); GI perforation (serious, sometimes fatal); infusion reactions (not as common as with chimeric mAbs); fatigue; minor bleeding (nosebleeds) in many patients; rare reversible posterior leukoencephalopathy syndrome (RPLS)
mechanism_of_action: Humanized monoclonal antibody against vascular endothelial growth factor A (VEGF-A). It binds VEGF and prevents it from interacting with its receptors on endothelial cells, thereby inhibiting angiogenesis (the growth of new blood vessels). Tumors rely on angiogenesis for growth and metastasis, so bevacizumab can slow tumor growth by starving it of blood supply and also 'normalize' tumor vasculature to improve chemo delivery
drug_interactions: Increases risk of bleeding with anti-coagulants or NSAIDs (though not absolutely contraindicated, but caution); when combined with sunitinib (tyrosine kinase inhibitor), there's a higher incidence of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (so careful monitoring); could potentiate risk of GI perforation when combined with inflammatory agents (like steroids or NSAIDs in some case reports); live vaccines should be avoided due to immunosuppressive effect of chemo regimens (bevacizumab itself not heavily immunosuppressive, but often given with chemo); combination with other chemotherapies can have overlapping toxicities (e.g., wound healing issues if combined with major surgery, etc.).
